Carers Centre Newcastle (CCN) is a VCS organisation working citywide to provide dedicated support and information to unpaid carers. Our services are available for any carer who lives in the City or who cares for someone living in the City. Services for carers include information & signposting, advice and advocacy, a listening ear, access to training, access to groups, complem,entary therapies, counselling, activities and events. As well as being an information and support service to carers we work with local organisations to develop better support services for carers and recognition of their important role. We also work to help carers support each other and to give carers a voice, for example, through participation in consultation events. The service is available Monday to Friday from 9.30am to 4pm.

Emergency Information Scheme which provides a vulnerable person with the opportunity to alert the emergency services of important information such as, medical conditions, current medication, a contact name and telephone number should an accident or sudden illness occur and even if there is a pet on the premises. The information helps the emergency services to deal quickly and efficiently with an emergency situation should it arise.

The project works with older people living in designated and sheltered housing schemes to promote active participationand social inclusion. Volunteers are recruited to support older residents at 4 sites across the City. Provision includes lunchblubs, arts and crafts, physical exercise through dance and Rookie golf, fundraising, outings special celebrations, regular quizzes and raffles, and, at one site,laundry and library services. the sessions also help carers who know their relatives are being supported at specific times. there are 4 sessions a week in Kenton, 2 in Scotswood and 2 in Walker.
We are open 9am till 4.30pm Mon - Friday, offering training and support in foundation skills such as literacy and numeracy and ICT to people with disabilities and /or mental health issues.

Baseline is a mentoring service which matches volunteer emntors with young people who live in the Tyne and Wear area, have a background of homelessness and need support making the transition into independent living. Baseline also runs group sessions covering issues affecting young people. The support given by Baseline is tailored to the individual needs of each young person. The mentoring support will usually be for 3 hours per week and will usually last 6 months for each young person.

Emergency accommodation for 16-25 year olds on a night by night basis, in the homes of volunteer hosts. We provide around 500 nights of accommodation per year, but frequency is responsive to need. The service offers support to young people 7 days per week.

We provide information, advice and support on all aspects of disability including welfare benefits, aids and adaptations to assist every daily living and direct payments. Our service operates from Monday to Friday, 9am - 5pm.

Organisation_Name: East End Health Community Health Project
Services_Provided: We help to rehabilitate isolated stroke victims and their families directly through our Stroke Rehabilitation Service to improve both the physical and mental health of our members. Runs two days per week.
Bathing daily Monday to Friday

Monday; Women's group- opportunity to have hair & nails done, arts & crafts, Bingo, hot meal, transport & occasional trips out. Tuesday & Friday; Men's Groups- variety of activities including pool, dominos, chess, scrabble, rookie golf, wii games. Hot meal & transport provided. All three groups are weekly and run from 9.30am - 3pm. Wednesday outreach group is held in a sheltered accommodation lounge and is normally a game of bingo followed by a fun quiz and refreshments. Thursday; Supported shopping trip to Tynemouth making it a social outing as well as a necessity. Assistance is given by staff & helps individuals retain & maintain their independence & choice. Monthly entertainment days- open to all older people in the local area - a hot meal, professional entertainer and loads of fun, also an opportunity to meet up with old friends and make new ones. Supported holidays twice a year to a venue of the service users choice. Volunteer & placement opportunities offering training & qualifications to help gain paid employment. This is ongoing and always operating at full capacity.

Support to individuals at the first stage of the patient/client pathway to make lifestyle changes for health improvement, including practical help with finding and using other relevant services, e.g. stop smoking service, referrals to other appropriate services and buddying to other services/facilities, signposting and information. Individuals are helped to identify and overcome any barriers to change, to set and achieve goals, and to maintain changes. Health issues include smoking, physical activity, healthy eating, wellbeing, drugs and alcohol and sexual health. The service operates in areas and with communities at greatest risk of experiencing poor health and low life expectancy. The service is client-led and is also delivered through session work. Health Trainers are drawn from and work in their own communities, bringing a unique knowledge and understanding of local health issues and concerns.

Practice based commissioning leads model in which local communities would have a voice, designing and commissioning services to improve mental and emotional wellbeing for; Older people (65+) with mild to moderate anxiety and depression in inner west of Newcastle; People with specified long term conditions, including diabetes and heart disease, in the outer west of the City.
Mental Health Day Service. A day service for people with mental health problems that focuses on helping people to access meaningful activities, education and work opportunities.
Mental Health Day Service. A day service for people with mental health problems with a focus on helping people access leisure and peer support activities.
Mental Health Day Service
Mental Health Day Service

The project provides support and training for up to 10 people with mental health problems in catering skills. In addition they also have access to external work placements as well as to a range of other courses including food hygiene. The programme is for up to two years and all our clients are supported by a Catering Supervisor / Empoyment Coach.

MHM provides an out of hours Helpline service delivering confidential emotional support and guidance to people calling the Helpline in Newcastle. The focus of the Helpline is to provide mental health intervention including crisis intervention.

Our Citizen Advocacy project provides longer term advocacy, usually with a volunteer advocate, to at least 40 vulnerable people per year. These clients are older people with disabilities (including mental health needs, learning disabilities and physical disabilities) who are in need of support to ensure their voices are heard in a variety of situations. The issues advocates help with include access to care, issues over health / medication, support with family issues, accommodation / housing, legal issues and financial issues. We also recruit, train and provide ongoing support to over 40 volunteer advocates. In addition we facilitate Advocacy Network Newcastle and provide advocacy support to its members. We also provide advocacy information and advice to other organisations.

Our Mental Health Case Advocacy project provides short term, issue based advocacy with either a volunteer or a worker. Many of the cases are complex and include issues such as support with access to services, meetings, care plans, review of medication, discharge from hospital, housing / accommodation, finance, safeguarding and complaints. We also recruit, train and provide ongoing support to volunteer advocates.

Information by telephone, email, post. Consultations for one hour in person. Group therapy for women aged 18 years and upwards (no upper limit) for one and a half hours per week. Letter, emails, calls responded to. Helpline. For people affected by eating distress / disorders and their carers.
This service offers support interventions to women experiencing issues around drug, alcohol and gambling. It also offers non user support and group work. The service runs Monday - Friday 9am-4.30pm.

Carelink is a telephone monitoring service which offers support to vulnerable people living in the community. We also prompt medications. Calls are made between 8am and 10.30am and in the evening 5.30pm - 8.30pm. We operate the service seven days a week including bank holidays.
To develop a range of opportunities to meet the changing aspirations of older people.
Takes a lead in engaging older people in decision making and contributing to community life
To provide older people with details of friendly, reliable and properly vetted hairdressers. It is designed for older women and men who cannot normally go out and access hairdressing service.
To help people over 60 years old in Newcastle to find tradespeople to carry out repairs and maintenance work in their homes.

Advice / information resource centre. Resource centre for older people in inner west Newcastle. Free confidential Drop-in advice & information service for people of pension age and their carers. Drop-in service is from Monday to Thursday 10am -1pm and Includes advocacy, benefit claims, housing Social Services referrals for assessments. Home visiting service for the house bound. appointments. Telephone advice line Monday to Friday 9am -4pm. Complementary therapies, leisure and learning. For people 50 plus. Including the following groups: walking. Swimming, local history, art, keep fit, computers, knit and natter. All of the above activities are provided either free of charge or low cost. The above are held Monday to Friday at various venues throughout the city.
representational advocacy and IMCA advocacy, this service has office hours of 9 - 5 Monday to Friday, but is provided outside these hours also, on any day of the week.

We provide a caseworking service visiting people at home when they request assistance or are referred to us for help. With regard to work done to enable clients to remain in their own home we are applying for financial assistance to purchase equipment such as stairlifts, bathroom adaptations, profiling beds or riser/recliner chairs when there is no statutory funding available or only partial grants.

We provide a full time service for homeless and supported clients in Newcastle, to be educated, trained and a pathway into employment, including accredited courses, CV training, job search, early learning, numeracy and literacy.

A primary health and social care resource for people who are homeless. Available for advice, information, support and advocacy on a wide range of issues including Health, Housing, Welfare Benefits, Local Services. Staff do outreach work in the City Centre and People's Kitchen. Opening hours Monday to Friday, 9-4. A GP is available each weekday at 12pm. A nurse is available for health advice, treatment and health promotion, baths, showers, clean clothing, minor healthcare and de-infestation between 9-4pm. A CPN is available for people who want help with a wide range of psychiatric services. We offer sexual health advice: condoms, pregnancy tests. We also run a needle exchange.

The ACE project supports chronically excluded people, a team of outrach workers made up of entirely ex service users establish contact with rough sleepers getting to know them, building up trust and connecting them into services such as the Day Centre, housing provision or local mental health and drug abuse services.

Ron Eager House Day Centre uses centre based support and attached outreach to access chronically excluded adults experiencing problems of alcohol or drug dependency, homelessness, mental health and other difficulties associated with social exclusion. Working alongside our existing ACE project (Adults facing Chronic Exclusion) and operating out of our city centre location, the project enhances and expands the current provision offered, providing a 'core resource' for health, drug and housing workers in the City to take their services to the user community. We aim to improve the health, well-being and personal circumstances of vulnerable adults living on the streets or in crisis. We believe that in order for our services to be truly effective, there needs to be an holistic approach so that ll aspects of those who are socially excluded are accomodated.

Tyneside Women's Health exists to support women to improve and maintain their mental health and wellbeing in order to achieve their full personal potential. We offer a range of mental health support to women, including welcome support, drop in support, mental health courses, support groups, counselling, therapeutic and creative activities, personal growth support and service user involvement and participation.

We provide a befriending service to residents in the West of Newcastle. This comprises of weekly (or more frequent if needed) visits to service users. Service delivered by volunteers who also accompany service users on shopping and GP trips. Other sections of our work include work with care homes to reduce isolation and improve inclusion in the community and exercise classes to help older people keep fit and remain in their homes for longer.
Speech therapy and help with speech problems following a stroke. Clubs meet three days per week - Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

Community Care Alarm service provides a mobile response, telecare and sheltered housing service across newcatle upon Tyne. We have approximately 960 sheltered housing tenants living in 26 sheltered housing schemes. We staff these 26 schemes with staff whp provide a housing management function as well as a warden call service. We also provide a mobile repsonse service to approximately 5000 clients ( tenure blind) as well as providing Telecare solutions on an individual basis

Provide a range of sensors within a persons home to alert the communal alarm provider Care Call that there may be a problem in the individual's home. These sensors include but are limited to, fall sensors, bed sensors, wandering client alerts, gas shut sensors.

On a daily basis Care Call provides assistance to almost 5,000 clients throughout the borough. This assistance can be responding to falls, toiletting, bathing, providing lunch, teas, giving advice, contacting next of kin / emergency services. The service also provides reassurance by conducting regular planned visits to vulnerable clients and liaising with the PCT identifying telecare needs to 387 clients at this moment in time.

Doncaster Young Carers Service offers support to young carers up to 19 years of age and their families. The service offers one to one support for young carers, family support, advocacy and referral to other appropriate agencies to relieve pressure from young carers. The service also offers issue based group work, social activities, and support plans for individual need. Doncaster Young Carers also have an active Young Carers Council and participate in in consultation and promote the needs of young carers and their families locally to influence local services and planning.

Rotherham Day Service provides day service for adults with physical, sensory, learning and communication disabilities and also some adults with head injuries. The service provides activities in-house and in the community, including education, skills, sports, leisure, life skills and independence and personal safety training, computers and IT training, including Internet and social networking. The service works in partnership with RCAT and the Workers Education Association to provide in-house accredited, and first step, learning opportunities. In addition, the service provides Independent Travel Training and some voluntary work support to enable disabled adults to engage with their local communities and become active citizens. The funding given by Rotherham Council is to be used to support 10 disabled adults to access voluntary work placements as an alternative to attending traditional day services.

Shield supports people living with HIV and their dependents to maintain their independence and a good standard of emotional and physical wellbeing. It does this through one-to-one assistance with housing/health/social issues, signposting to other agencies, emergency food and toiletry hampers, counselling, hardship clothing and house goods, hospital visits, home visits and a womens support group activities. The social womens group takes place once a week, all other one-to-one support takes place across Mon to Fri.
Dementia Support, Sign posting, Information and advise to people with Dementia, Day Care
Handy person service provides a range of services to older people including DIY jobs , plumbing, guardening, decorating, safety and security devices
Provides advice and support on a regular basis offering signposting to available services and offers Assistive technology

A needs led and responsive information and person centred support service to visually impaired people, their family and carers. This is done at point of diagnosis and ongoing as required by the Eye Clinic Liaison Officer. The Welfare Rights and Administration Officer conducts home visits to visually impaired people, specialising in benefit enquiries but also acting as advocate in more general terms. The Volunteer Project matches volunteer befrienders to visually impaired people to visit them in their own homes and support them in getting 'out and about' in the community. The Eye Clinic Liaison Officer, Volunteer Outreach Coordinator and Welfare Rights/Information Officer provide full time services during weekdays.
A group ran by carers which offers advice and information, friendship, social excursions
A group ran by the community providing basic IT Trainnning and computer equipment to enable older people to Impove computer skills and prevent social isolation

RAP works with adults and young people with learning disabilities. We ensure adults with learning disabilities understand their choices and rights and have a voice about their lives.

Employment service for people who have a learning disability and who live in Rotherham. Key Objectives include finding paid employment, work placements, voluntary work and providing in-house work preperation courses to people who aspire to work.

Self Peer and Group advocacy service together with employment and work skills opportunies. Speakup also produces accessible information and builds the skills of people with learning disabilities through a variety of training programmes.

Mencap Active is a service that gives people with a learning disability the chance to learn and develop essential life and social skills, through attending a variety of leisure activities in their communities.

The REMA project works with vulnerable people from communities which have disproportionately low access to social care, health, and welfare support, to make sure they receive information and proactive encouragement to enable them to get the support they need. In 2010/11 this was set up and has been particularly useful in communicating the principles of self-directed support and personalisation to people who have not been reached by traditional communication methods. This includes non-FACS eligible people with autistic spectrum disorders, learning difficulties, or low level mental health problems; carers; self-funders with dementia and their families; BME communities; ROMA community; Travelling Community.

Tassibee takes referrals from health and social care organisations, and self-referrals, from adult vulnerable women mainly from BME communities who are seeking advice on health and disability issues, or assistance to access mainstream services - often because of language or cultural barriers. The project provides a safe environment particularly for older women and women living with disability who are socially isolated and are at risk of social breakdown.

URC is a Christian organisation that has been involved in the provision of community services ensuring that social, physical and spiritual well being of those in need. Project aims to provide a weekly coffee morning, with regular lunches and occasional special events.
Weekly companion and social events for people over 50+ . The cmputer club is scheduled for 2 x 12 week blocks.
A group of older people who meet weekly for a range of activities and general support. Have speakers, visits out using the Family Centre minibus, lunch club every month and other activities

The Good Sehat association supports South Asian women who are suffering from mental health problems and physical disabilities to socialise and get advise on healthy eating, being more active and practical support in cooking healthy food.

Provides an avenue for people of any age with special needs to meet and socialise. Provide a variety of activities eg dancing, sports, table games, drama workshops and occasionally have day trips and residential trips.

Organisation_Name: Home Valley MS and Neurological group
Services_Provided: Aims to mutually support anyone with a neurological condition. Meet weekly at the DRAM Centre and includes yoga, reflexology, lunch and a speaker.
Community based group for older people. Provide a healthy 2 course lunch cooked on the premises by West Yorks Probation (community payback) every Monday.

The 'supporting volunteers project' supports vulnerable individuals to volunteer at The Welcome Centre preparing and giving out food packs and volunteers are encouraged to get involved in the management of the project.
The Welcome Centre provides food and toiletry packs to vulnerable adults in crisis situations. Most of the adults who receive the packs are referred from Social Services.
The Church runs a coffee morning in their community rooms for frail and elderly members of the community who are particularly vulnerable. Most of the adults who attend are in their 80s and 90s.

Ambitions is a social enterprise that supports young adults with learning disabilities. They focus on encouragingth epeople who go to be fit and healthy and more aware of looking after themselves; all this is achieved doing activities that the users enjoy. This contract will support their Horticultural project starting 01/04/10. Two parts will be: Support the ongoing horticulture project and 'Sow it, Grow it, Eat it programme.

Organisation_Name: Huddersfield Deanery Project for Older People

The 611 Centre provides a drop-in for adults who have alcohol and drug addictions, mental health problems, are homeless etc. As well as providing a warm environment and food, they also provide practical advice to try to help them to improve their situations.

Run activities for the senior citizens of Kirkburton, Highburton and surrounding area, liaise with Kirklees Social Services and other bodies to be able to provide a wide range of services and provisions for old people in the community.

BRC's mission is to provide Batley and its locality with community services that enhance the quality of life for individuals, families and groups, by fostering access to information and opportunities for empowerment, social inclusion, support and friends. Generaton Dominoes meets a few times a week and encourages older men to get out of their houses and be involved in their community. They provide transport for those with mobility problems and also support and run community events.

Batley Owls is based in a Sports Centre and encourages older people to join in physical activity and generally improve their health. Many of the members are particularly elderly.
Heckmondwike Ladies Group meets fortnightly and supports women to get out and support eachother. They have a structured programme of activity including speakers
An older people's group in Marsden who have been asked to ressurect dance activity for older people in the village. This will support many elderly people to stay active doing an activity they enjoy.

The group provide information and support for the people and their carers who suffer from a rare condition Charcot marie tooth disease. The group recognises the need to make people aware of this rare condition that disables the use of arms and legs. The group is run by volunteers networking with GP surgeries and local authority providing regular befriending support and guidance over the telephone 7 days a week for the patients and carers. Due to the nature of disability many membeers cannot attend regular meetings. The group seeks networking, advising, providing personal support to the sufferers and their carers and act as a voice in discussions.

Organisation_Name: Colne Valley MS/Neuro Self Help Group

Club is for senior citizens and older residents of the Mirfield District. Meetings held every Friday with speakers, film shows and musical groups. Tea and biscuits also provided.

Generation Xchange is an innovative and creative intergenerational skills exchange scheme which has been developed by a committed voluntary sector led partnership, supported by the local authority. It aims to address widening gaps in understanding and tolerance between younger and older citizens in order to build stronger and more cohesive communities. Individual projects include : Lunch clubs in schools, Silver surfers, Cooking clubs, Literacy mentoring, Clay project.
As part of the scheme's Implementation Plan, some of the key outcomes are that the older people involved will experience: an improved sense of health and wellbeing / a reduced sense of isolation / an increased ability to make a positive contribution / a greater satisfaction with home/neighbourhood / a reduction in the fear of crime. Close involvement has taken place with York Consulting, the external evaluators, to ensure that evidence of the impact and effectiveness of the projects is generated. Age Concern take an active part in running the various activities in the project.

Provides opportunities for people with mental health problems to recover their confidence and self-esteem by accessing a range of leisure, therapeutic and social activities in a safe, friendly and non-judgemental environment. This is achieved through a conmbination of support such as : Promoting a positive self image; benefits of one-to-one support; Accessing local community facilities; Access to education and training opportunities; Involved in the planning and governance of the service etc.

Move Ahead supports brain injured people and their carers. The charity is based in Wakefield, West Yorkshire and currently runs weekly therapeutic activities for people with brain injury and their carers. The Charity was started eight years ago by a group of carers wishing to enhance the long term services for the brain injured. The Centre aims to provide therapeutic employment, enhance skills and foster social well being. It will also offer Carers a variety of activities and a vital support network.

Support to individuals with mental health needs to move into independance in the community.

The service is based in Hulme and offers adults with learning disabilities visual arts workshops on a one-to-one sessional basis. The project aims to enrich the lives of people with learning difficulties to impove their outlook and self-confidence.

Organisation_Name: Victoria Avenue East Pensioners Ex-Servicemen's Club
Services_Provided: A weekly meeting place for the elderly to reduce their lonliness, where they can participate in social activities, including bingo, dancing and quizzes. We also arrange excursions and the occasional party.

Services to support Chinese elderly carers, including Chinese elderly carers corner (once a week), pampering days, respite breaks, day trips and residential trips, emotional support, language support, welfare advice support and home visits.
Project Kwan Wai provides support to people within the Chinese community of Manchester with mental health problems.
Luncheon club meals service and day care service, support to elderly and vulnerable adults within the Chinese community of Manchester, including support for their carers.

Support to young carers within the Chinese community of Manchester. Services include access to support network, provision of respite, provision of home care to assist the carer and the provision of advice and information. Services are provided based on the needs of the individual

A range of exercise, cultural & social facilities to promote healthy lifestyles for elderly tenants through exercise, information & advice, ballroom dancing, line dancing, the Radio Project with Wythenshawe FM, indoor bowling, art & crafts & group session
Saturday Club: A meeting point for social and recreational activities within a completely inclusive environment. Fun Bingo: Social group for elderly single people.
Community Cafe, snacks and meals to local people twice weekly
Special services for elderly people in the community with an emphasis on healthy living to improve well being.

A comprehensive range of alternative therapies individually tailored to support individuals with existing illnesses or disabilities with both physical and emotional theraputic support. This support is intended to help the individuals maintain their independence living in the community.
4 course quality lunches with a choice of menu for a range of people from the local community
Full Range of 1:1 Counselling for people seeking advice, support and guidance
Vocational meetings for people in the community with mental health issues
A range of activities from armchair exercises and gym activities to art and craft and stroke prevention seminars
Handyman service for older people offering DIY and maintenance available 5 days a week
Provides opportunity for older people to make new friends, join in a variety of activities and receive a healthy home cooked 3 course meal.

Centre provides support to patients, carers and families from the Oldham area who are affected by Cancer. The funding provides for Carers group on a monthly basis.
24hr service where alarm units fitted into clients' homes that present telephone calls into the Helpline team when activated.
Cross tenure housing related support to vulnerable customers that are 60+ via a home visiting service.
"Living Support Networks" of 9 vulnerable adults and a volunteer living independently but within the same locality.
Drop in centre for elderly. We provide social interaction, guidance, support and refreshments (free of charge).We supply information regarding health, safety and crime prevention.

Support, development, facilitation and promotion of service user involvement & self-advocacy. Consultation with service users on changes & issues relating to the services they receive. The service usually operates 9am - 5pm, Mon to Fri with evening & weekend working when necessary. The service operates across the metropolitan borough of Rochdale.

We provide long term 1-1 advocacy for people with learning disabilities through volunteer citizen advocates. We provide short term immediate crisis advocacy through our 2 part time co=ordinators (paid). We organise regular training workshops for both partners and advocates, we work with people in the black and minority ethnic communities to promote advocacy.

the single sex service is an outreach respite service for young women with learning disabilities from the South Asian communities. The young women accessing the service are entitled up to 6 hours of break per week. During the break the individual is supported and encouraged to undertake activities, person centred planning, access course, undertake voluntary work, employment opportunities and are supported in future planning. Staff also undertake areas of work withthe individual which includes confidence building and assertiveness skills. The service exists as a way of encouraging transitition for the individual onto other services, courses, employment and learning for the future. It also exists as a way of supporting the individual until she is competent at managing for herself and until she has set clear goals for the future which she no longer requires support with.

The Aashiyana carers group aims to provide support to carers caring for someone with a learning disability from the South Asian community. Carers attend activities every week which includes fitness sessions, walking groups, flower arranging, caring with confidence course, reiki sessions and the expert patient programme. Carers also attend the monthly carers support meeting which takes place on the last Tuesday of every month

Luncheon club service for older asian users, including gym sessions, health related talks, newspapers & entertainment. The LC service is available on Mon, Tues, Weds & Thurs between the hours of 11.30 and 2.30 a minimum of 48wks per year.

Providing young carers assessments, a range of support services & activities for young carers & their families to give young carers a break & help improve their situation. The service is ongoing & frequency variable dependant on need. Support services are available weekdays & activity based groups/breaks are at least weekly.

Arrange carer breaks for the carers of those with mental health problems aged 18-65yrs as the result of an identified need from a carers assessment. The breaks can range from a couple of hours away from home to short breaks away.

Completion of carers assessments where there is no care co-ordinator or where there is conflict between service user and carer. Carer Support on a 1-2-1 basis for agreed interventions. This is usually weekly initially but tapering off towards the end of the intervention. Each can vary in lengths of time but 6 months being about the average. The Carer Support worker facilitates two carer support groups on a monthly basis, one in the community and one at the hospital where carers can call in for advice and information as well as listen to speakers. Signposting / referring to other agencies as appropriate.

Volunteers are recruited to support clients with mental ill health to reduce social isolation. The co-ordinator supports clients and volunteers to access training including NVQ's and also local groups and leisure activities. The co-ordinator also supports a volunteer and service user run group which is held once per week and reduces social isolation, provides a meal and activities and occasional trips and meals out
Littleborough Older People Welfare Monday - Friday.
Lunch Club - Middleton, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday. Hot meals and social contact
Handyperson Scheme, Mon - Fri. Support to people who live alone and who are isolated, with small household repairs.
Friendly Visitor Mon - Fri. Support to people who are living alone and who are isolated.
Asian ladies lunch service, Mondays only. Culturally appropriate service and the opportunity for social contact
Day services, Mon - Fri. Stimulating environment which allow housebound older people to maintain social contact.
We provide a Mon-Fri support for clients with enduring mental health within the community to maintain their tenancy. We see clients from two hours a week depending on what input they need.
A legal advice & representation service to older persons regarding matters relating to community care. Advocate for Older Persons

mental health advocacy service for people who are in hospital & community to assist them to access services, housing, benefit & debt assistance, therapeutic services, support at meetings, hospital appointments, tribunals, MHRT, CPA, general support & understanding of rights. Assist expression of views & concerns, explore choices & options. Support with any conditions/restrictions under the mental health act & any medical treatment they may be receiving, information & increased involvement about care & treatment. Access to make complaints, help challenge decisions. assist with accessing legal support. we have contact with service users on a regular weekly/daily basis & also carers care co-ordinators, etc, family & friends who may be involved in the persons care & well being, IMCA has specific rolls with DoLS & help the person & representative understands the effect of DoLS.

Apna Ghar Caters for the BME community over 50's. We provide 3 services, daycare, drop in & luncheon. Many of the service users are socially isolated and suffer from mental health

Breaks for carers in their own homes or at venue of their choice. Personal care, companionship, support with general tasks as required. All on regular basis - usually weekly. Specialist care for people with complex health/social care needs. Family support as they define through care plan

Provides short breaks for people with disabilities and complex needs, this enables carers to enjoy quality time and a break when much needed while the person cared for enjoys leisure, social and educational activities and develop their skills at the gateway centre, in community and day trips out. Few examples of the actvities: Computer skills, arts & crafts, ball games, badminton, pool table, wii disco, trips to cinemas, bowling, museum, sports activities at the base and other sports venues, and full day trips out of the borough. The short respite break takes place every Saturday except national holiday weekends.

Helping Hands is an established social enterprise which has been delivering a
Handyperson and Minor Repairs scheme in Salford for the last eleven years.
Founded in 1998 by local residents, Helping Hands' business has grown incrementally
by the expansion of its customer base, diversification of its services and broadening
the source of funding grants.
The primary objective of the Company is to offer a subsidised service to the 
disadvantaged and vulnerable, particularly older people. The business model it employs 
enables subsidised work to be financed from a mixture of grants and cross-subsidy 
gained from its non-subsidised domestic and commercial customers. In 2005 Helping
Hands secured a contract with Salford City Council to carry out Priority works to the 
elderly and vulnerable people of Salford. This work is completed at no charge to our 
client group, this is funded through the City Council, the works involve making our
client group feel more secure in their homes and goes some way towards the upkeep 
of the property. Helping Hands also completes a number of works on behalf of
occupational therapy, home improvement agency, the council, private landlords
 and housing associations.

Variety of services in a day care setting for people with acquired brain injury to maximise self autonomy. Specialist resource centre for people following a traumatic brain injury or neurological diagnosis e.g. severe head injury, brain haemorrhage, brain tumour and conditions such as brain cancer and stroke. Provision of vocational and physical rehabilitation to improve health and well being, increase skills levels and support people to access employment and volunteering opportunities.

CALL provides a range of services designed to improve the mental and physical wellbeing of those affected by cancer and other life-limiting illnesses. Services are tailored to individual needs and frequency is determined on a case by case basis.

This scheme does not provide a service purely for carers, this scheme provides practical and emotional support to both users and carers. Crossroads support is individually tailored to meet the needs of each user/carer and is totally flexible and adaptable around their needs. Individual care plans are agreed between Crossroads, the user and the carer.

Professional Support is provided on a person centred basis to clients without which they would be unable to live independently in the home. This grant is particularly for counselling services for people with mental health problems/older people

This is a person centred scheme which includes for service users (and carers if appropriate) befriending services, a weekly Gateway Club, swimming and drop in sessions, crown green bowls, indoor bowls, regular meals out, walks, cinema, theatre trips, annual holidays, support to people and their parents/carers plus education, housing, safeguarding support as needed

Daily ward visiting service. Detailed advice to patients and carers about a variety of issues but common queries are welfare benefits and debts. We identify benefits entitlement inlcuding community care grants and disability and sickness claims, we help to complete the forms amd then chase up payments. We have a specific specialism in neurolgical issues and we undertake advice clinis in the neuro wards organized by the social workers. Provides very intensive advice literally by hospitals patients bedsides to aid quicker and more effective discharge into the community

Community support day care groups and reablement for stroke survivors with Communication disabilities. The Salford Communication Support Service works collaboratively with the Speech & Language Therapy Department to establish goals and needs for adults affected by communication difficulties as a result of having a stroke. We provide practical tools and peer support to help people rebuild their confidence and develop new ways of communicating. The service offers support and an opportunity to practise communication strategies in weekly groups, and a fortnightly group which provides a continuing support/peer support for stroke survivors. We also offer befriending/emotional support, practical advice and information as well as assistance with access to local leisure and social activities.

Scheme_Name: Salford Information, Advice and Support Service
Services_Provided: This person centred Stroke Association service is designed to provide information, emotional support and practical advice to people affected by stroke, and also their families and carers. Our staff work alongside a multidisciplinary team of professionals across health and social care to provide information and advocacy support for stroke survivors and also their families as they work towards regaining independence. We will contact users within 72 hours of a stroke being confirmed, usually in the acute setting. We will provide emotional support to family/relatives as necessary, helping them to understand stroke, what is happening etc. Service users receive continued support via face to face or telephone contact with a minimum of three contacts post discharge from hospital. Support is offered for a period of 12 months initially, this can be extended where a need is identified.

Individual and peer support for people with early stage dementia. The Buddy Service provides one to one and peer support to people with mild to moderate dementia. This is provided via weekly activity groups and through weekly visits to clients at home, assisting them to go out and pursue hobbies etc.

Individual and peer support for family carers of people with dementia. Carer support provides one to one support to family carers of people with dementia. This includes emotional support, advocacy, information, signposting etc. We also enable peer support via a range of support and social groups. We organise regular trips out for carers and 3 six week training courses per year

Organisation_Name: Salford Talking Newspaper for the Blind
Scheme_Name: Salford Talking Newspaper for the Blind
Services_Provided: Sending weekly audio recordings of local news to visually-disabled or reading-disabled people in the City of Salford, and a monthly magazine tape. We send out each week a free news recording on memory sticks (previously on cassette tape) to blind, partially-sighted or otherwise reading-disabled people within the whole of the Salford area. This contains local news and other information of local interest. We also send out a free monthly magazine tape.

50+ physical activity programme . Range of services for the over 50 population across the city including chair based exercsie classes, a choir, mentor training and workshops for trained mentors, a 1:1 service for those who are housebound and falls prevention sessions. Chair based sessions are delivered in 12 Community Rooms, 12 Day Centres, 3 Hospital Units, 15 Residential Homes, 31 Sheltered Housing. Frequency of sessions: Mentors in care and residential settings deliver on a daily or weekly basis in over 30 venues. 26 community sessions are delivered weekly by volunteer mentors. The choir practices weekly and performs accross the city regularly. 1:1 services are delivered weekly to cohorts of 4 people at a time in 6 week courses. Over 200 mentors have now been trained. The project not only addresses falls prevention and aims to increase activity levels, but there is also a major focus on reducing social isolation and prolongong independant living.

This is an oureach service for Older visually impaired individulas living in Salford. It is a needs-led service providing practical advice and support to enable people to lead independent lives within their communities. 
Henshaws Salford Community Outreach Scheme provides specialist information, advice and support to people who are visually impaired (VI) and living in their own homes. The project aims to enhance their quality of life by enabling them to live as independently as possible and to make informed choices about the services available to them. The specific aims of the project are:
To assess the needs of older people with a visual impairment, whether they are social or practical, in order to identify appropriate services to enhance everyday life.
To recruit and train volunteers to address these needs and to provide expertise and support to these volunteers to ensure the delivery of an effective service.
To provide access to specialist information in the appropriate format (audio, Braille, large print etc) on the various benefits and services available in the Salford area to support VI people.
To provide access to social groups both in Henshaws Resource Centre and across the City of Salford contributing to reducing the social isolation often experienced by older VI people.
To provide ongoing support on a needs led basis to clients, their family and carers.

The Information and Support Programme is open to individuals newly registered as sight impaired or severly sight impaired, living in the Salford area. The Salford Information and Support Scheme runs 3 times per year, and provides information and advice to people newly registered as sight impaired or severely sight impaired, in a supportive, group environment. 
 nature of the group allows face-to-face contact with representatives of both Henshaws and the other local agencies who are making presentations to the group. Participants are often referred for ongoing support during the actual time of the session; however the vast majority of referrals are supported outside this provision by the separate, Henshaws' Salford Outreach Service for the Visually Impaired.

Community based mental health advocacy service. We provide a mental health advocacy service based in the community. The service is available 10am -4pm, Monday to Friday. People can self refer or come via another agancy such as GPs, Primary Care Mental Health Teams, Social Workers, Community Mental Health Teams or other Voluntary sector agencies etc.

Scheme_Name: Providing support & services for people living with, or affected by, HIV
Services_Provided: GHT provides a range of services including, but not limited to, advice & advocacy, peer support, financial support, counselling, group spaces & events and Living with HIV residential courses. The organisation provides these services all year and our offices are open all day 5 days a week and selected courses and events are additionally held in the evenings and weekends.

This MJF scheme provides services both for carers and service users. MJF provide a one to one support through befriending and visiting for elderly and isolated people. Escort and transport to appointments. Help with an escorted shopping spree. Support to carers by befriending and visiting the cared for person. We organise social trips for both carers and service users. Patient Support Service pre and post discharge to and from hospital. There is provision of 1-1 carers support, advice and assessment through social work support on a daily basis. There is also provision of carers sitting service via individual breaks and group support MJF also provides a range of welfare services to the Jewish community of greater Manchester. MJF have a Carers' Advice Worker who carries out carer's assessments for carers in the Jewish community. MJF also provides events, activities and support for carers, in addition to a quarterly carers' newsletter. MJF also operates a grant scheme enabling carers to apply for a grant to take a break of their choosing.

Grant is provided for a target group of vulnerable adults who have long term illness/chronic conditions. Scheme cannot be accessed by general public. GPs refer people to the scheme and it is appointment only system. Clients get specialist tailored advice/advocacy e.g. in welfare benefits, debt advice, housing advice. Enable people to improve the quality of their life and wellbeing. It is the scheme's sole function and is separate from the day to day CAB Activites

Grant is provided for a target group of vulnerable adults who are housebound through disabilites. Scheme cannot be accessed by general public. The scheme runs via an appointment only system. Clients get specialist tailored advice/advocacy e.g. in welfare benefits, debt advice, housing advice. Enable people to improve the quality of their life and wellbeing. It is the scheme's sole function and is separate from the day to day CAB Activites

the deaf gathering meets the last Thursday in the monthat 7:30pm until late. The gathering supports a network of deaf people in salford with all aspects of community life, this includes meeting on a social bases and providing oppertunities for social support and access to information.

Drop in, lunch, therapies, counselling, information and training, helpline, Saturday school, Independent and community wellbeing centre,HIV testing
Drop-In Centre is available Tues & Thurs 11am - 8pm, Mon & Weds 11am - 5pm & Friday 11am - 4pm, Saturday 11am - 2pm.
Lunch is available Mon - Fri 1pm - 2pm & Dinner Mon, Tues, & Thurs 17.30pm - 18.30pm. 
Therapies available 5 days a week Mon - Fri.

Beeches Group available on Mondays 5:00 pm - 8:00pm
ESOL/Weekly Family Saturday School available on Saturdays 11:30am - 1:30pm

Person centred support for the families of people who have severe mental health problems, who are themselves vulnerable and also for some service users. Support includes befriending, information and advice, and more practical support.

Educational and employment support for people who have severe mental health problems, supporting people to remain in employment or gain qualifications and/or voluntary work to help them gain employment.

Organisation_Name: The Princess Royal Trust Salford Carers Centre
Services_Provided: Carers support, advice and information, young adult carers service, carers emergency card scheme, carers personal budget scheme. Salford Carers Centre offers a number of services to informal carers. This includes information & advice, carers support, training, help getting back to work, regular free newwsletters, coffee mornings, activities and events and support to access other services. The Centre also provides a specific service for carers aged between 16-25, as well as young carers (8-18). The Centre works closely with Salford PCT working in surgeries and with the local hospital and mental health services. The service is open from 9.30 - 4pm Monday to Thursday and 9.30-1pm Fridays. The Centre administers the carers personal budget scheme and carers emergency card scheme.
Passenger transport service in accessible minibuses, for vulnerable people. Available Monday to Friday; also at weekends (subject to availability).
Person centred service for vulnerable older people. Includes generic advocacy, utilities support, information and advice, care options advocacy and care homes advocacy.
Disabled Living provides impartial information and advice to disabled and older people relating to equipment to enable people to retain or regain their independence and improve choice.

Practical Support eg provision of breaks (both respite and short care) and emotional support for users and families affected by Autistic Spectrum Disorders. Breaks are run on a weekly and monthly basis; telephone support and information is available every week day. Scheme assists both service users and carers

Centre opens Monday to Friday inclusive from 9.30 to 4.30 p.m. The main aim is to provide culturally sensitive Day Resource services, including Luncheon Club, Transport, Recreational facilities, including customary food, social activities, entertainment, games, outing Day Trips, Long Trips, Home/Hospital visits, Preventative Health Care, Medical Talks by specialist consultants and community Nurse, REhabilitation facilities i.e. Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy, Chiropody, Exercise classes, Screening Clinics, Advice, Advocacy 7 Information on Welfare benefits and Educational IT learning facilities.
Day centre for vulnerable groups, providing preventative services to help reduce isolation and to help people stay in the community.
Day centre for vulnerable groups, providing preventative services to help reduce isolation and to help people stay in the community.
Day Care open every day, casual drop in, activites such as flower arranging, salsa dancing, tai chi, also provide lunch & dinner

We are an advocacy organisation for adults who have a learning disability. We provide a five day a week service, helping people to speak up, and we inform them of their rights and choices. We also support individuals.

Provides a short break for full time carers for BME women once a week they proivde:
Moral support
Physical support
Provide information
Give them confidence
Listen to their needs
Act on their behalf
Person centred day care, providing targeted preventative services to allow its vulnerable users to live independently without the need for more targeted care managed intervention.

Providing community care service i.e. running day care centre for elderly, disabled people. Activities include reflexology, yoga, arts classes, and mobility exercise. Advice & Information on welfare benefits, health & social care issues etc. Home visits on request. Health lectures and outdoor trips.

The Mental Health worker runs various groups to support clients with mental ill health. The worker also supports some individuals in other ways to achieve independence such as by ensuring they are accessing services they need.

Scheme_Name: Support for Salford Older People Carers
Services_Provided: We provide support and breaks for Salford Older People Carers. These activities include carers corner, luncheon club, singing club, ballroom dance club, festival celebrations, health exercises (eg Tai Chi, Chair exercises, Table Tennis club) etc. We also provide language support services, access to carers services and health/benefit talks for the Salford Carers.

This is a RAP equivalent scheme (if the service was for assessed clients and included within the care plan / support plan) and would be included within the service types self directed support, professional support or other (or within the RAP C returns if the individual was a carer). The scheme constitutes a programme aiming to increase levels of physical activity, emotional health and well being and social inclusion (for the client group substance misuse).

This scheme is aimed specifically at providing person centred help to vulnerable young adults (of the client group substance misuse) and their parents/carers. The service includes professional support and advocacy/information & advice provided to an individual where staff of the scheme come into direct contact with the person receiving help. The service helps the young adult live in the community, in their own home. The service also has a specialist parents and carers service.

Organisation_Name: Equipment Clinic for Deaf/Hard of Hearing People (known as Hospital Support - Deaf Services)
Services_Provided: Hospital Support

Ace Cycling provides the opportunity of a cycling experience for all regardless of disability. The equipment that is available can accommodate wheelchair users and those people who require direct support or supervision ie LD clients, visually impaired. There are adult tricycles and Quads for those who are independent but need extra stability to ride. The Scheme also offers a variety of hand bikes for those users who cannot pedal but have functional upper limbs. The Scheme is located at a local running Track and a purpose built cycle circuit allowing secure cycling off the road system but allowing a wide range of experiences for the users. The scheme allows both carers and service users the ability to enjoy a social activity together.

Scheme_Name: Hospital Support Service for Visually Impaired
Services_Provided: Advocacy

The mail reading service was set up to support people who are Deaf within our communities.Their first language is BSL not English and the service we provide is vital in assisting them to understand their mail we do this by means of having BSL translators available who can read the information and then communicate it back so that the Deaf person understands what is being written and can then act on it if needed.This can be anything ranging from making medical appointments, pension information, bills such as gas, electricity and council tax. In some cases it is necessary for the BSL Interpreter to contact the sender of the mail to get clarification so that the customer has all the correct information.

Social Inclusion - Weekly term time art group based at Tameside College but taught by a member of the OPT-in team. The aim of the group is to offer support to people with mental health issues, to develop skills and confidence and to provide a progression route for those who wish to join the college BTEC Art and Design course.

Social Inclusion - Weekly football for people affected by mental health issues. The group plays mainly at Medlock Sports Centre but they also take part in social outings and trips away. The activity improves health and fitness and helps to maintain mental well being.

The co-ordinator will identify the needs of the person affected by stoke and provide appropriate support and advice. The co-ordinators also set up and facilitate long term support groups, art groups and psychological support groups. The communication support service offers one to one support and group support to people referred by the speech and language service and other affected by aphasia.

Prevention and early intervention services for older people in Tameside. These include handy person and home assessments, befriending, hospital aftercare, freedom and movement, information and advice. These services are provided Monday to Friday. (First Call can be provided at weekend).

Scheme_Name: Luncheon Club & ESOL (Exercise, Art & Crafts, IT Basic)
Services_Provided: Luncheon Club

The Clarendon group have been in existence for nearly 20 years and meet on a Tuesday evening at a local social club. The membership is currently 150 people with a waiting list of over 50. They have guest speakers, bingo, entertainers, provide information and peer to peer support to members and have day trips out for members also.

Scheme_Name: Age Concern Tameside - Buddying & Befriending Scheme
Services_Provided: The service is available for a maximum of 12 hours. These hours can be used in a variety of ways to suit the individual, i.e. it might be 12 weeks x 1 hour, or it might be 6 weeks x 2 hours. The service will be offered to meet specific outcomes identified by the Advisor and the service user, eg by the end of the 12 week period, the individual is able to get on a bus and make her own way to a social group, following a period of the Buddy accompanying the person to the club, and encouraging them to make friends, gain confidence etc. It might be that an individual wants to be able to get out to the shops again, after losing confidence following a fall.

Scheme_Name: Age Concern Tameside - Community Falls Groups
Services_Provided: Facilitates 8 community falls groups to people referred to the service who have fallen or are at risk of falling. The funding was to fund a part time worker who will expand the original service by planning and delivering more falls groups and facilitate more outreach work. The worker also delivers home visits to clients.

The group meets on a monthly basis and is open to older people who want to take part in group activities such as Tai Chi, crafts, Singing for Health, author visits and specialised talks. The group is held in Droylsden Library.

This group exists to provide paid opportunities for people with a learning disability. It provides packaging services for local companies. The group provides training, arts and crafts, IT skills and gardening opportunities for people. The funding was to purchase a green house and gardening equipment to produce a range of horticultural items including plants, fruit and vegetables to be sold to the public or exchanged at the park Cafe in Hyde.

Facilitated by Tameside Sports Development, the project hosts 6 gentle exercise classes that are held weekly in 6 New Charter Sheltered Housing Schemes. Classes are open to residents and members of the community. Referrals are also made into the classes via the ACT Community Falls Groups. The sessions maintain/increase independence and are particularly aimed at those people at risk of osteoporosis or falling. Sessions are led by a qualified postural stability specialist exercise instructor.

The group meets on a weekly basis in the local library at Hattersley. They meet to learn new computer skills in a relaxed environment. It provides social opportunities as the group regularly take trips out to take photographs and video which they then translate onto the computer.

The group has been in existence for 30 years and operates as a luncheon club, but with the funding it has been able to extend its activities to run topical sessions after lunch such as home safety, health and keeping fit. The funding was a contribution towards rent, transport, refreshments and activities.

To provide a door to door transport link to local supermarkets for older people and people who struggle to access public transport. The link will enable people to visit supermarkets for their fresh food shopping which links to the Health Improvement agenda and it will also provide the opportunity for people to get out of the house and enjoy the social element of the trip through meeting and engaging with other travellers in the supermarket cafe whilst waiting for the bus to collect them, thereby reducing social isolation.

This is an Art Club that is based in Stalybridge and meets weekly. The funding enables the group to buy equipment and material at a reduced cost. The group also have demonstrators that come in to teach the members new skills etc.

The Freedom Club operates twice a week and is a group for people with physical and sensory disabilities. It is based in Hattersley and provides the opportunity for people to attend the 5 hour sessions to enjoy activities such as bingo, card making, art and craft, pool, darts, lunch and social activities such as day trips out. The group has grown in membership and the funding was to purchase equipment, refreshments, rent and trips.

Miles for Smiles is a Volunteer Driver Scheme that is operated through Tameside Volunteer Centre. It provides a transport service for people who are unable to access or use public transport to attend medical appointments such as GP/Hospital appointments. They also provide a transport service for CORA users who wish to attend gentle Exercise, Health Walk activities in the borough.
