Organisation_Name: African and Caribbean Mental Health Services (ACMHS)
Services_Provided: ACMHS provides a range of culturally appropriate mental health services to African and African Caribbean people suffering from mental ill health living in Manchester, Trafford and surrounding areas. The service with respect to this survey is to provide casework to Trafford residents, which includes assessment, management of care, hospital visits, representation at tribunals, advocacy and the writing of psychiatric reports. Frequency depends on the clients' needs. Support is also provided to carers and families. The Carers Group provides practical and emotional support as part of an overall care package to people looking after those who suffer mental ill health. In addition, carers can access information, other relevant services and short respite breaks.

Organisation_Name: African and Caribbean Mental Health Services (ACMHS)
Services_Provided: ACMHS provides a range of culturally appropriate mental health services to African and African Caribbean people suffering from mental ill health living in Manchester, Trafford and surrounding areas. The service with respect to this survey is to provide casework to Trafford residents, which includes assessment, management of care, hospital visits, representation at tribunals, advocacy and the writing of psychiatric reports. Frequency depends on the clients' needs. Support is also provided to carers and families. The Carers Group provides practical and emotional support as part of an overall care package to people looking after those who suffer mental ill health. In addition, carers can access information, other relevant services and short respite breaks.

Respite breaks and support for families affected by Autistic Spectrum Disorders. Respite activities rea run on a weekly and monthly basis, telephone support and information is available every week day. In addition, provides direct support to people with autistic spectrum conditions through providing 1-2-1 support, activities and social interaction within a safe environment; including support to become more independent and access education, training and employment. This acts to increase confidence and enable individuals to increase their confidence around participating within their communities

blueSCI is an Arts, cultural wellbeing service, providing a wide range of interventions and opportunities to residents of Trafford. These include:  Low intensity interventions Brief intervention  Alcohol Motivational life coaching Community capacity building Local area knowledge.  Supported self advocacy-Supporting individuals to overcome barriers and achieve aspirations as part of a mental health recovery programme.Navigating pathways related to life domains; Employment, Education, Family and Communities, Housing and Neighbourhood, Faith and Culture, Sport and Leisure, Services and Volunteering Practical coping and resilience motivational techniques Person centred facilitated access to information advice and guidance  Specific focus on accessing local community resources Meaningful occupation linked to aspirations  volunteering Books on prescription and other guided self help resources
Support for people with life-limiting illness - befriending, group support, respite care, support for hospital appointments/treatments
Themed, residential holidays for adults with learning (and physical) disabilities. Taking place around the UK & Europe. Fully inclusive and staffed to appropriate levels with our own care staff.
We provide two luncheon clubs each for older people living within Sale and the surrounding area.

Organisation_Name: Elizabeth Fitzroy Support Trafford Community Day and Support Brokerage Services
Services_Provided: We have a contract with Trafford Council to provide Support Brokerage to adults with disabilities who are being offered a personal budget for their social care services.

Based within Trafford, Genie Networks strives to improve the quality of life for deaf people and their families. We endeavour to actively promote citizenship by empowering deaf people and their families to develop independence and a positive perception of deafness. We aim to remove barriers that cause discrimination as it is our belief that social inclusion and the full participation in society is a fundamental human right.We provide a range of services for all deaf people including deaf, hard of hearing and deafblind people. Deaf people have difficulty accessing mainstream services because of language barriers; many deaf people use sign language to communicate, a majority of mainstream services have difficulty understanding deaf people's needs. Deaf people including deaf parents can access the following services at Genie Networks: Support Brokerage: We provide support for deaf people who require assistance and support with personalised budgets. Job Club monthly: support with telephone translations, booking interpreters, writing CVs, searching for jobs, interview techniques etc. Drop In services twice per week: We provide a Drop In twice per week for families to attend and meet other deaf people. We have a social room with tea and coffee, toys and activities for children, internet access for young people and a lending library with specialist books and DVD about deafness. We provide one to one support where deaf people gain support with letter translation and translated telephone calls; this is to support them with arranging appointments and accessing mainstream services independent of their families/carers. We also priovide monthly talks on health and wellbeing topics in sign language. Deaf people feel they miss out on this information in the media; we invite services to come and give a talk and share information. Learning skills workshops monthly: the aim of these workshops is to develop deaf people's life skills, independence and confidence. To date we have provided workshops on confidence building, money management and Disability Rights. Hard of Hearing Forum and Afternoon Tea Sessions monthly: these groups are specifically aimed at people who are hard of hearing and do not use sign language. The Afternoon Tea session is the same format as the Drop In and the forum is to support Hard of Hearing people to raise issues around access and barriers to services, we also use this as an opportunity to consult and gain feedback from hard of hearing people about our services. Outreach/Advocacy work daily: we provide support in the wider community, deaf people's homes and in joint partnership working with mainstream services. We support deaf people to access services independently of their families and carers. Friends of Genie monthly: This group is aimed at deaf services users. The group is especially adapted using resources in sign language and a deaf friendly format for service users to give feedback on how we can improve and develop our services.

Scheme_Name: Providing services for people living with, or affected by, HIV
Services_Provided: GHT provides a range of services including, but not limited to, advice & advocacy, peer support, financial support, counselling, group spaces & events and Living with HIV residential courses. The organisation provides these services all year and our offices are open all day 5 days a week and selected courses and events are additionally held in the evenings and weekends.

Scheme_Name: Advice, Advocacy & Information, Community Care & Luncheon Club
Services_Provided: Centre opens Monday to Friday inclusive from 9.30 to 4.30 p.m. The main aim is to provide culturally sensitive Day Resource services, including Luncheon club, Transport, Recreational facilities, including customary food, Social activities, entertainment, Games, Outing Day Trips, Long Trips, Home/Hospital visits, Preventative health care, Medical Talks by Specialist Consultants and Community Nurse, Rehabilitation facilities i.e. physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy, Chiropody, Exercise Classes, Screening clinics, ADvice, Advocacy & Information on Welfare benefits and Educational IT learning cacilities.

We support older South Asian persons and their carers through outreach work and weekly drop-ins. Support includes information, advice and practical and emotional support to help access appropriate health and social care.

TMHAS offer a none assessed 1:1 instucted advocay service to adults in the community who perceive they have a mental health problem. TMHAS offer a none assessed service to people who are informal and detained under the Mental Health Act, and both instructed and non-instructed advocacy to qualifying patients under the statutary IMHA service

PHAB (Physically Handicapped and Able Bodied) club is a service user led organisation based at Sale West Community Centre. There are over 100 members, supported by 25 volunteers, there are no paid staff. PHAB provides a regular social club two nights a week for adults aged 18 and over, the majority of people have a learning disability and or physical disability. The club provides regular respite for parents/carers. Phab also provides volunteers with experience of working with people with learning disabilities, people with physical disabilities , people with mental health needs and people with profound disabilities.

New way forward is a Trafford-based mental-health charity that provides groups and activities for adults affected by mental ill health. The charity is open seven days per week and volunteers, many of whom are former or current service users do the bulk of the work. New way forward is committed to help alleviate some of the difficulties, which individuals with mental-health problems often experience. As an organisation, we promote positive mental health, whilst being aware of mental illness. We respect and recognise individual experiences and feelings and promote the many skills of the people with whom we work. All new way forward services are user-demand or user-led, and we continually modify and monitor our services to preserve our person-centred aims and to promote recovery and a better quality of life.

5 x Support groups on a monthly basis, Our support groups provide a opportunity for social interaction, shared experiences and activities that enable people with dementia and their carers to socialise, have fun, increase confidence and learn from shared each others experiences. We provide an information service that receives calls from people with dementia and their carers, We signpost them on an individual basis to the right support for them to ensure that they are able to receive an accurate diagnosis, receive appropriate support and maintain skills through participating in community activities and resources. We promote relaxation and healthily living to increase confidence and to maintain a healthy life style.

Carers Assessments, healh checks, home visits, helpline support, emergency card scheme, training, holistic therapy services, events, counselling, advocacy, informaiton and advice, social events, meetings and forums. Social events and meetings take place monthly. Advocacy and assessments take place every day with our caseworkers seeing a carers on average 4 times. Our helpline operates Mon - Fri. Counselling takes place every day with carers having on average 5-10 sessions.

Crossroads Care provides practical and emotional support to Carers who are responsible for the care of children, young adults, adults or older people at home, who have a physical/sensory disability, learning difficulty or who are chronically ill. Crossroads support is individually tailored to meet the needs of each family and is totally flexible and adaptable around their needs. Individual care plans are agreed between Crossroads, the Carer and the person with care needs. Crossroads will nominate a trained Carer Support Worker to a family and they will provide whatever support is required to relieve the Carer of their caring responsibilities which can range from emotional support through to more specialised tasks such as peg-feeding and administering medication. Crossroads Care provide a trained Carer Support Worker to a family in order to provide a range of support to relieve the Carer of their caring responsibilities. The Carer Support Workers assist the person with disabilities to live in their own home through the provision of emotional support, direct personal care and supporting them with activities and interests within their own home or supporting them to access activities within the local community
Advocacy service to assist people to make a complaint about Social Services.

Organisation_Name: Pakistani Resource Centre (Trafford South Asian Mental Health Service)
Services_Provided: The following services are provided to South Asian individuals experiencing mental health problems, their carers, families and community members: Advocate on service users and carers behalf to Mental Health Consultants, GPs, Community Mental Health Teams, Care Coordinators, Benefits Agency, Housing or other specialist services Case work (outreach work and home visits) Attend ward rounds and visit service users on a mental health ward Cultural and linguistic interpretation in South Asian languages of Urdu, Punjabi and Hindiò Co-work with mainstream mental health services  Involved with Care Programme Approach / Reviews Joint mental health assessments with statutory services. This is also provided in South Asian languages of Urdu, Punjabi and Hindi. Preventative work - working with service users, carers, their families and communities to raise the awareness of mental ill-health and the support that is available. Create opportunities, deliver, facilitate, support and motivate service users, carers and communities to access/attend training, courses and meetings to lead more productive lives. Encourage service users/carers to participate in social activities to build their confidence and reduce social exclusion. Empower and support service users, carers and communities to be involved in research focusing on BME communities needs. Partnership working to develop social integration and community cohesion. Deliver diversity training to professionals and communities on South Asian communities beliefs and perceptions regarding mental illness. Promote equality in service delivery Attend case reviews with Social Services regarding child protection issues, which may concern our service users. Involved in strategic partnership work to deliver services to BME communities i.e. TCCP, Rethink, Trafford CDW, blueSCI, ACMHS etc. Signposting service users to other services that can add value to their lives.Drop-in for service users and carers: Women's drop-in "Arzoo" every Wednesday 1.30 - 3.00pmThe drop-in promotes health and well-being e.g. sessions on highlighting the significance of healthy eating, sessions stressing the importance of keeping fit and regular exercises as well as preventative work undertaken.Services specific to carers:TSAMHS also works with the carers of the service users. At any one time this means that work is undertaken with carers alongside service users and their families in a holistic manner in regards to mental ill-health. The service provided to carers includes linguistic interpretation, one-to-one support and advocacy. TSAMHS also receives a grant to provide culturally sensitive and appropriate short breaks to South Asian carers.

United Response is a national charity that supports people with learning disabilities, mental health and physical impairments. In Trafford we support people in providing supported employment to a range of people and this service is offered every day and can include weekends.
WRVS Luncheon clubs promote nutrition and healthy eating and give a comfortable environment for service users. Open daily/weekly

Age Concern Trafford provides a wide range of services - the information in this form relates to the one grant funded service it provides i.e. Speakeasy project and should not be seen as an inidication of the whole of Age Concern Trafford's services. Speakeasy is a volunteering service where 98% of the volunteers are aged 50+ and they carry out a range of communication activities with their peers, including supported information on a wide range of subjects in person and by telephone, befriending, silver surfer tutoring and peer consultation. The service runs on weekdays across the Borough of Trafford.

We are a Home Improvement Agency. We provide technical support and advice for older and vulnerable people requiring help with larger home repairs, assistance with benefit and grant applications including DFGs. (This includes technical drawings, specifications and supervision of the work to satisfactory completion.) We run and maintain a list of reputable contractors so that Trafford residents can have confidence in approaching contractors. We run several handyperson projects: minor adaptations, hospital discharge and a subsidised service for small repairs.

This group runs predominantly for older people living in the area who may be socially isolated, bereaved and or lonely. The group provides a 2 course meal and social contact. The group meets every Tues / Weds and Thurs 11.30am - 1.30pm
A weekly day service - Tuesdays for women and Thurdays for Men, aimed at South Asian ethnic groups. Includes: lunch, arts and crafts, light esercise, group discussions and guest speakers.

Trafford Active Citizens Team (TACT) is a volunteer-led service which provides driving and befriending services to people who have been assessed as requiring Adult Social Care Services. There are currently 15 volunteers in a combination of administrative, befriending and driving roles

Scheme_Name: Day Care and Associated Support Services
Services_Provided: Day Care, Luncheon Club, Advocacy, Carers Support Services, Community Outreach Services, Transport. These services are provided on Modays and Wednesdays from Harry Lord House and Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from Claremont Resource Centre.
A course in self defense for people with Mental Health Problems ideally twice a week. This service has not yet started but is envisaged top be up and running soon (January 2011)

Communication support has a central role in delivering personalised services.The Communication support co-ordinator plays a key role in early intervention,promoting inclusion and developing social capital as well as safeguarding adults in vulnerable circumstances.They are skilled at identifying models of intervention,some therapeutic,some task centered and working through with people the outcomes to be achieved.People who use service are encouraged to be more personally ambitious and to better articulate their wishes.They also undertake brokerage and navigator roles as well as supporting self assessment.

EBOOK PROJECT - To ensure that carers have better access to high quality information about local services, their rights and support from a range of professionals across the borough. To enable professionals to have accurate information at their fingertips for carers. The ebooks are provided to carers as and when they need it.

Much of the work the Fed do is that of Outreach to its local community including older people, families and younger people. Specific services are established for carers as well as people with a mental health problem, dementia and lonely isolated individuals. Volunteers are provided to support people in the community to services such as befriending, shopping services, welfare checks, to name but a few (see data below).
Assisting older and disabled people to remain living in their own homes by providing a range of services to carry out repairs, improvements & adaptions

Scheme_Name: Specialist Information & Advice Service for Carers of Older People
Services_Provided: Many older carers say they have experienced levels of depression and physical disability related to being a carer and became financially worse off when they took on the role. Through the provision of caring and timely, information and guidance, which is responsive to the needs of the individual older people are supported to manage their own changing circumstances and remain as active and independent as they can.

Older People in Liverpool, who require assistance with their daily living, are provide with the opportunity to take control and have choices over how they wish to live their lives by becoming an employer. A team of trained Direct Payment officers at Age Concern Liverpool provide a professional and caring support service to assist older people through the process of becoming an employer. They will stay with their client and continue to provide as much or as little support as required to enable older people to manage their Direct Payment and support them on any issues or concerns which may arise ensuring that needs and aspirations are met. The service is available Monday to Friday during office hours and at evenings and weekends by prior arrangement.

Scheme_Name: Specilist Information & Advice Service for Older People
Services_Provided: Information & Advice Officers provide a personalised service, offering, guidance and support through the vast range of issues which affect older people. An understandable explanation of the choices available is provided by the officers and where required, assistance in accessing entitlements.Issues ranging from general enquiries up to complex community care issues and tribunal representation. Through the provision of a telephone helpline, appointments drop-in and home visits we offer a free, personalised service of independent information and advice, to older people, their friends, families and carers

Under this funding programme we provide services and activities for older people including a twice weekly shopping service, thrice weekly luncheon club, weekly chair based exercises, monthly information sessions, 6 social events per quarter including monthly tea dances and quaterly concerts/celebration dinners, 6 'away-days' each year all of which provide opportunities for older people from different parts of the city to come together and participate in different activities. Liverpool Citizen Advocacy aims to tackle the social exclusion often faced by people with 'learning difficulties' through the co-ordination of a series of social events, activities and projects. The Learning Disabilities Inclusion Project recruits volunteers who support individuals on a one-to-one basis. The volunteers form partnerships that are focussed on the rights of the individuals who might be at a disadvantage and/or socially excluded. We also have a paid issue-based advocate working with people who have a specific issue. We hold regular social networking events (about once a month) at various locations across the city.

Community and support services for Deaf, Deaf/blind and hard of hearing people. The centre provides a range of facilities and services for groups, individuals and their families. Groups meet every week and courses delivered every week. On average, 250 - 350 people attend the centre every week.

Employment Information & Advice - provide support, advice and guidance across a range of skills through one-to-one sessions with Employment Advisors. Support people who have, or are recovering from mental health problems and wish to return to paid work, voluntary work or training. our aim is to encourage each individuals sense of independence, purpose and fulfilment and develop the skills necessary to manage their mental health problems and return to work or training. We meet new clients on an initial assessment session, then 2 weeks later we accompany the service user to their chosen placement/training or paid work etc. on commencement of their placement we take the service user there for the first 2-3 sessions. this is reviewed face-to-face on a 3 monthly basis but we maintain weekly phone contact with all clients. This enables people to be a part of and live in the community.

The Support Brokerage Service provides specialist, techinical advice, information, guidance and support to service users having Direct Payments or who are self funders. Referrals are made by Social Workers for service users who have been assessed as having critical and substaintial needs. Support Brokers visit the service users in their own home and provide specialist service giving detailed information, advice and guidance on all aspects of community support to maintain independence in their own home, including employing a Personal Assistant. The service runs 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday (except bank holidays) and includes a dedicated telephone line for Social Workers to make contact. In addition, assistance is provided to establish and maintain effective financial management systems and support with the paperwork audit trail for Direct Payments.

Cheshire Centre for Independent Living is a user-led organisation, providing a range of support services, driven by the needs and aspirations of disabled people and carers. Our aim is to empower disabled people to direct their own care and to promote greater independence, choice and control over their lives. Our range of services to promote independent living include:-(1) Direct Payments Support service including support for full cost clients regarding all aspects of directing their own care and managing a direct payment. CCIL also deliver a number of non-council funded support services that further compliment self-directed support that address many barriers to accessing independent living. (2) Independent Mental Capacity Advocacy (IMCA) (3) Continuing Healthcare Advocacy

To provide short breaks to carers of Older People usually on a weekly basis and to ensure appropriate substitute care is provided for their clients during this time. This funding is currently only available for carers in the former Macclesfield Borough area.
To provide short breaks to carers to Carers in the Cheshire East area, usually on a weekly basis and to ensure appropriate substitute care is provided for their clients during this time.

Carers Grant - Take-a-Break - Adults with Physical Disabilities, Older People, Cameo (early onset dementia) and Carers Group (CGEXT037). Each group meets one Thursday each month for 4 hours, allowing the carer a meaningful break away from their caring role. In addition this allows the person with care needs the opportunity to explore new activities and interests in a social environment. A Carer Support Worker can be provided, if required, to look after the person with care needs to enable the carer to attend the Carers Group. The figures included in the return relate to the Cameo group.
To provide short breaks to unsupported "Hidden" Carers in Cheshire East who care for Older People and Adults and ensure appropriate substitute care is provided for their clients at this time.

The aim of CERS is to provide the carer the "peace of mind" that in the event of an emergency affecting them, their loved one will be looked after. Outreach Workers from the team draw up a Contingency Plan with the carer and person they care for. In the event of an emergency, this plan is then put into action, co-ordinated by the on-call Outreach Worker. The support covers up to 48 hours, extending to 72 hours over Bank Holidays.
To provide group and one to one social skills support for adults with Aspergers Syndrome in the Cheshire East area. This is for the benefit of Carers and the people with cared for needs they support.

Social Work Servies, Technical Services, Communication Services (interpreting) and Deafblind services for Adults and Older People with a hearing or dual impairment. Mon-Thu 9.00am to 5.00pm & Friday 9.00am to 4.30pm. (No child client numbers included in this survey).

Social Work Servies, Technical Services, Communication Services (interpreting) and Deafblind services for Adults and Older People with a hearing or dual impairment. Mon-Thu 9.00am to 5.00pm & Friday 9.00am to 4.30pm. (No child client numbers included in this survey).

Disability Information and Signposting Helpline for any queries relating to disability of any form. The enquires we receive can range from 'where can I get Advocacy help?' to 'where can I purchase a RADAR Key?'. There are 25 subject categories we use and we often get an enquiry which will not fit any of them. The query could be on what local organisations may help the individual, where could a person with particular needs find a place for a holiday, or find sports/leisure facilities to suit them. We try to answer, get answers to or signpost people to where the answers can be given to any question with an element of disability to it. This might be the person has a disability, or the service providers specialise in disability issues.

The purpose of the Disability Information Bureau is to provide an accessible, confidential and continuously updated range of services for disabled people and any other person interested in disability related matters. Our Vision is an Cheshire East where disability is not a barrier to opportunity and fulfilment by enabling people to achieve their full potential. We offer the following services: Information/Advice/signposting service; Welfare benefits/direct payment assistance and form filling; IT courses; Adaptive technology; Wheelchair and Equipment Loan; Radar Keys; Employment assistance and support for thise on health related benefits; volunteering service to assist people to build social skills, confidence and their employability.
Citizen advocacy through volunteers. Statutory advocacy (IMCA/IMHA). Crisis advocacy provided by employed advocates. Daily or as otherwise required.

Demonstration and sale of aids and equipment for visually impaired people; provision of low vision service throughout CECPCT area; provision of social, recreational and educational facilities for visually impaired people; provision of awareness-raising training. Low Vision, Resource Room and general advice and information services for people with a visual disability.

Scheme_Name: 056 Assistance in operation of Resource Centre
Services_Provided: Demonstration and sale of aids and equipment for visually impaired people.

The Carer Development Service offers its Carers a choice of options. These include personal development through confidence building, access to college courses, training, employment and also support with job retention. Carers are met with with on an individual basis at a mutually agreeable location at a frequency that suits their individual needs. Correspondance is also carried out over the phone and via email where appropriate. Employment support for Carers of people experiencing mental ill health.

To be responsible for providing information, advice and support to carers of people experiencing mental ill health and promote provision for carers in line with current national objectives; e.g. Carer groups, 1:1 support, signposting, carer assessments, liaise with professional when required, emotional support, etc.

Employment Development Service supports people who have a primary diagnosis of mental ill health to access work opportunities under SPW rules, part time or full time work, paid or voluntary work and to retain that employment. Support is also offered to the employer if appropriate. We also assist people to access college and training opportunities and signpost where appropriate. In addition, we deliver a confidence building course aimed at allowing people to recognise their existing skillls and abilities and how to build on those. We offer interview technique advice and training and CV preparation.

Support Delivery to enable informal carers of adults with physical and/or sensory impairments to have access to a community support group. The scheme offers the provision of peer support, social interaction - networking, social events and partnership opportunities. Services are introduced on a face-to-face basis and delivered at the venue the contractor arranges for hire.

We meet up every other Monday. We have several speakers which the group enjoy. We go out socially which is the aim of the group to provide sufferers with confidence to get back in the community and provide their carers with the opportunity to relax and enjoy the experience, to exchange views and exchange ideas which help to make their lives a little better.
Day Care and Day Opportunities

Swanswell is a charitable trust with 40 years experience of delivering successful community-based programmes Our current portfolio includes a wide range of services to support people, their families, carers and affected others with problems related to drug and/or alcohol misuse.
Swanswell brings together many different resources required to reduce harm and help people to lead happier lives. Working in partnership with healthcare providers, local authorities, national probation services, government agencies and third-sector organisations; this holistic approach removes barriers and offers a real prospect of change.
Swanswell develops tailor-made solutions that provide practical, physical and emotional support by taking a client-centred approach with individual service users.
Staff, work with users individually in their own home and in the local community; working to find practical ways to overcome difficulties by offering support, advice and information, this includes:
Applying and the right benefits 
Budgeting and paying bills 
Helping users to keep their house safe and in good repair 
attend appointments 
get into voluntary or paid work 
develop leisure interests 
Swanswell work with any one over the age of 18 years old and living in Coventry and have problems with drugs and/or alcohol and are putting their ability to retain their home at risk.

A floating support service for vulnerable adults

This support service is aimed at vulnerable adults that suffer from learning disabilities. The level of service can range from giving advice to family members and service users or be more hands on approach. Similarly, to the mental health floating support service, one to one sessions are also carried out with people who suffer from learning disabilities. These sessions are used to help service users to develop their personal skills and to enable them to gain confidence to try and lead more independent lives.

This service has two elements to it. The first is a drop in service which allows individuals/families of suffers of mental health conditions to access an information service. General advice and guidance is given every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, this is a more one to one approach.
Every Tuesday and Thursday the service provided is more community based; groups of the community who fall in to this category (mental health) are given support. The aim of both the drop in and the community based sessions are to empower this client group to try and live more independently in the community.

The Residential Advocacy Project provides an independent ear for people and their families who are either in, or about to go into Residential Care. Should the resident wish it, there is someone to speak on their behalf.
The Project aims to help people living in nursing homes and residential homes (including private, voluntary sector and local authority care homes) in the Derby City areas.
The Project also offers a service to older people who are considering moving into a care home and to older people who want to live independently in their own homes. 
The Project aims to provide advocacy support to older people who feel isolated or unable to represent their own wishes and would like an independent person to speak for them or to support them in speaking for themselves.
Derby City Council funds 12.5 hrs of Advocacy in Derby City and anyone can refer themselves or someone else to the Advocacy Project. Referrals are also encouraged from care home residents, older people considering moving into or out of residential care, social workers, nursing staff, care home staff, carers and relatives.

Scheme_Name: Rethink Leicester City Carers Support Services
Services_Provided: Rethink facilitates the promotion, planning, delivery, development & management of the running of four 12 Week Carer Education Training Programmes to Carers aged 18-65+ whose relatives suffer from severe mental illnesses across the city of Leicester. These include Schizophrenia,Bi - Polar Disorder. Psychosis, Manic Depression, Psychotic Depressions & Obsessive Compulsive Disorders. Rethink has a variety of Trainers in all areas of expertise in mental health & legal issues on the 12 week Programme. These include Social Workers, Community Psychiatric Nurses, Carer Trainers, Occupational Therapists, Family Therapists, Doctors, Consultant Psychiatrists, Pharmacists, Mental Health Lawyers, Solicitors, Complementary Therapists & Psychotherapists educating the Carers on all aspects of mental illness. Rethink runs 2 afternoon and 1 Evening Carers Support groups per month. We provide social, cultural, holistic, health care & training activities at these three monthly support groups each month which caters for Carers social, cultural, health care & holistic needs. A total of 36 groups are run each year. We identify & address Carers needs by providing the necessary support, advice, Information, education and services of the highest standard to those experiencing severe mental illness their families and their Carers. We support Multicultural Carers with their social, cultural and health care needs via one to one support, carers support groups, home visits, telephone, educational support and signposting to other services. We treat Carers as individuals providing a holistic approach to cater for all their needs promoting & improving their positive mental health & well being reducing their stress levels as a result.

Scheme_Name: City Carers Care & Share Multicultural Drop In Service
Services_Provided: Rethink promotes, the marketing, development management and running of a Multicultural Drop In Service for Carers of all ethnicities aged 18-65+ whose relatives suffer from all mental health problems in the city of Leicester. This service is set up to meet the social, cultural and health care needs of all Carers of all ethnicities. The weekly Drop In Sessions runs for 4 hours twice a week for 12 months a total of 104 sessions per year. The Tuesday Drop In Service is held at St Matthews Neighbourhood Centre from 12am - 4.30pm and the Thursday Drop In Service is held at the West End Neighbourhood Centre from 12.30pm - 4.30pm. As a result, all Carers are given the opportunity to benefit from accessing this weekly specialist mental health drop in service. A variety of social, cultural, holistic and health care activities are run at the weekly drop in sessions which promotes Carers positve physical & mental health & well -being reducing their stress levels in turn. Carers are valued and empowered to share their experience, knowledge skills with one another buiding up positive relationships with Carers of all cultural back grounds and ethnicites. All Cultural Festivals are celebrated at the Multicultural Drop In Service and all Carers enjoy participating in the variety of activites at the service. Carers love coming to the weekly sessions meeting up with other Carers in a similar situation building up concrete friendships with each other sharing their experiences, knowledge and skills with each other.

Scheme_Name: Savera Resource centre Day care service
Services_Provided: Savera Resource Centre provides service to people suffering with mental health difficulties and support their carers. Saffron Support for Elderly People (SSEP) promotes the independence for frail elderly local residents and enables them to participate in community based activities. SSEP also facilitates a lunch club twice weekly and a social group once a week. The Project Worker also carries out home visits to help reduce isolation felt by many local elders.

Silverstrand Lunch ClubWe provide a lunch club for Afro-Caribean elders Weds & Thurs 11-4pm. We aim to provide social where members can come & have group dicussion, games and interactionwith each other. By group interaction we can identify any needs which can be met by services.

Support for tenants in St Matthews estate age >60. Day care activities, shopping, home visits, prescription collection, laundry, & sitting services, daily. Emergency keyholder service, information & advice. Some night visits.

We provide a drop-in style Lunch Club 3 days a week for those in need. The main clientele use the centre to prevent social isolation. The client group varies tremendously, however the majority are men in their 40's and 50's. Our clients suffer from mental health issues such as depression and many suffer isolation through relationship breakdown or alcohol abuse - particularly those 'on the edge' of society. We also have a group of older clients who risk social isolation. We serve European style meals that consist of a main meal and pudding with a drink. Meals are served 12pm - 1pm Monday, Wednesday and Fridays

Advice and Information provides face to face and telephone advice, Monday to Friday, 50 weeks per year. 
Service Users contact the duty desk for advice and information via telephone, emails or attends Vista in person. Provision of an Advice and Information Service point of contact at the Ophthalmic Outpatients Department of the University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust (Leicester Royal Infirmary) for those with little or no sight (including those who also have a hearing impairment). We Refer blind or partially sighted people who are eligible for statutory services under Fair Access to Care Services (FACS), on to the appropriate service within Vista. 
Provide information to anyone resident in the City of Leicester who is registered as blind or partially sighted or who is print impaired and has indicated that they would wish to receive regular information in Braille, large print or on tape or Asian Language on tape.
Subscription to Talking Books Service. THIS SERVICE IS ACCESSABLE TO BOTH THE CARERS AND SERVICE USERS.

Rehabilitation - Support for those with sight loss. Provides one to one training and advice to maximise independence and social inclusion following sight loss. Monday to Friday, 50 weeks per year. There are 5 distinct areas to rehabilitation: (i) Teaching of daily living skills which may involve the use of an aid or gadget, which will be provided on loan by Vista.(ii) Teaching of communication skills. (iii) Mobility training.(iv) Providing information about services provided.(v) Group work eg Coping with Sight Loss courses. Maintain comprehensive register of blind and partially sighted people in City area

Scheme_Name: West Indian Senior Citizens Project Lunch Club
Services_Provided: Lunch club for African Caribbean Elders

Scheme_Name: West Indian Senior Citizens Project sitting
Services_Provided: The Sitting Service is 7 per week, we visit our elders to give support for carers to " Take A Break" and provide friendship and an opportunity to chat and give reassurance and support, we also provide the domiciliary service to the service user. THIS SERVICE IS PROVIDED TO BOTH CARERS & SERVICE USERS. THE CARERS IS GETTING RESPITE AND THE SERVICE USER RECEIVES DOMICILIARY CARE .

Scheme_Name: West Indian Senior Citizens Project home visits
Services_Provided: The Home Visit service is a vital for the Organsiation. We provided a Comprehensive Quality Service for our valued African Caribbean Elders to enhance their quailty of life. A warm and friendly home visit, will brighten up those service users who are lonely, isolated, limted in mobility, in need of meeting up with friends, and to introduce them into having a nice hot Caribbean meals during the day. Help is also provided with benefits, housing, respite, immigration, and other vital help that is required, from both Service User and Carer. The majority of clients are too proud to asked for help, or don't know of what services are avaiable. When a home visit is carried out it provides Service User with confidence to make that first move to take up one or more of our services. This service is provided 5 days, 6 visit per week.

East West Community Project provided luncheon club services to the elderly and frail people in Leicester. We provide Gujarati-style vegeterian meals Monday to Friday. The main objective is bring people with similar needs together who are suffering from social isolation. We also run various activities such as day care every Tuesday and Fridays. We also run various other community activities such meals on wheels services,Yoga, Exercise for elderly, e.t.c.

We provide a free independent culturally sensitive advocacy service for people with dementia who are living in the community.
To enable people with dementia to remain in the community where this is feasible and possible and their preferred choice.
We are responsive to individual and cultural needs in support of people with dementia.The services we provide are consistent with both national and local priorities for people with dementia -to empower and enable service users through representation if they cannot participate themselves, to promote a degree of self-advocacy and autonomy.

To provide Face to Face Support for Individual Service Users and their Carers
To provide a home visiting service to carers of people with dementia providing advocacy, information and advice.
To attend and/or facilitate liaison/contact meetings in the city of Leicester in order to respond to the support needs of carers.

Dementia Support Worker - 8 hours per week to provide support information and advice to those suffering from dementia, their families and carers. This service is available through home visits, by telephone, by e mail and by post as required and continues throughout the course of the illness or as required. Referrals are received directly from the families and carers and also from other health professionals such as Social Workers, Occupational Therapists and the Community Psychiatric Nurse.
CLASP provides support for carers including direct advocacy support, information provision.
training, befriending and counselling

Advocacy and information to people with mental health issues and to their carers. This involves regular one to one meetings, home/hospital visits, telephone conversations, and correspondence to support individuals in having a say in the service and treatment they receive.
Preventative Wellbeing Services which promote healthy living, social support and companionship, information & advice.
Sitting service for full-time carers to allow the carer to go out

Provide stroke survivors, families and their carers with emotional support, practical support, advice & information. Act as advocates on behalf of our clients when necessary. Provide a range of information including specialist information packs for stroke survivors and anyone else that needs information on Stroke. Sign post to appropriate agencies.
Infrastructure support service -volunteer drivers etc. to enable service users to attend day centres & social events.

This scheme provides services for both Clients and Carers. 1)Individually tailored, short ,regular, much needed, planned respite breaks for unpaid family carers enabling them to sustain their caring role and outside pursuits by means of the provision of fully trained , consistently reliable, carer support workers,who respect the individuality of Carers and people with
care needs and seeks to promote their choice, independence, dignity and safety. We believe that Carers must have access to high-quality services that enable them to fully benefit from a break from their caring responsibilities.
We will respect the privacy and personal choices, lifestyles, customs, cultures and values of each person for whom a service is provided and seek to involve Carers and people with care needs in the provision, management and development of services provided by us. These breaks are usually provided on a weekly basis however some are fortnightly and or monthly

Scheme_Name: Circles of Support across two localities
Services_Provided: Funding is largely focused on development and facilitation of Circles of Support - providing volunteer-based mentoring and befriending support for young people and young adults with learning disabilities, enabling them to access the community and community amenities with peer group support, and to develop practical life skills. individuals develop choice and control through monthly Circle Meetings for planning and review of activities. In addition to this, group activities take place, with staff and volunteer support, also enabling people with learning disabilities to increase their access to the community, and exercise choice and control in planning what these activities are to be.

Scheme_Name: More2Life for people with complex needs
Services_Provided: Improving access and reducing isolation for people with LD

We provide two taster sessions per month. Our activities are either exercise or craft based. We encourage a healthy lifestyle and promote good mental health wellbeing. By offering these taster sessions, people are able to socialise and try an activity that they might never have tried before. By attending these sessions many of our clients take up the activity independently.

CheeRing is a telephone befriending service for elderly isolated people over the age of 65. We offer a telephony support group which operates once a week for 45 minutes. This gives a group of people including a CheeRing Befriender (who acts as a facilitator) a chance to "meet" down the line for a chat, a chance to reminince, debate matters of interest and generally interact with one another.

We hold two club meeting days a week where members socialise, learn new skills and generally participate. We arrange pub lunches, day trips out, bar-b-ques, visits to theatres and we arrange an annual holiday each year for our members. During club days we have bingo, quizzes, various table games, keyboards, floor games, guest speakers, chair exercises and musical entertainment. We are the only club of its kind in Basildon and surrounding districts helping to reduce social isolation.

Organisation_Name: PAVIS Foundation for Visually Impaired People
Services_Provided: Going out into the community attending events, visiting people in their own homes, information giving and sharing. People may be referred or self refer and some are met when visiting the low vision clinic at the local hospital.

The Shawstep project provides support to individuals with mental health needs who are seeking paid and voluntary work, and training. Clients are referred via GPs, statutory and voluntary organisations, or can self-refer. The project has funding via Essex County Council to provide activities to improve client's confidence and wellbeing. We put on events, such as outdoor activities and a reading group, several times a month.

The advocacy service provides adults with learning disabilities advocacy support to help them with any issues they may have to ensure their voice is heard and they have the opportunity to have the best possible chances in their lives. Our advocate is available Monday to Friday between the hours of 9.30am and 4.30pm.

The TopCats Social club is a weekly activities session for adults with learning disabilities living in the Castle Point area of Essex. The club meets every Tuesday evening from 7pm to 10pm at Castle View School in Canvey and they have the opportunity to do a number of activities like cooking, playing pool, arts and craft as well as maintaining and making new friendships.

To assist in any way possible during recovery, and rehabilitation in the long term. We strive to improve the quality of life and assist stroke survivors and carers to live independently in their own homes, and remain within their community. Activities (therapeutic) are provided for stroke survivors at our centre, as well as respite and training for carers, families, and the wider community. Healthy lifestyles are promoted for stoke prevention and awareness. We hold carers' meetings on a monthly basis. Our centre is open 5 days a week. We provide two services in the Dovercourt/Harwich area. We also provide a home visiting service, and a counselling service.

Services include one to one confidential counselling / talks / displays / and advocacy. This is a support service - similar to care managed professional support - but direct access due to the hard to reach nature of the client group. It provides support with a wide variety of social care aspects - not just treatment and support around alcohol addicition. For example it supports people to claim benenfits, secure employment and identify suitable housing options. The focus of the service is that wider determinants of a persons life need to be addressed before they can successfully break away from an alcohol addicition.

Our Day Centre based in the Michael Flanders Centre is a co-location with Ealing Council's Day Centre. We are open 5 days a week from Monday until Friday from 9.30 until 4.30. All our service users are assessed prior to them using our facilities and as such we provide a duty of care towards them with regular reviews of their needs, incorporating both physical and psychological well being. We provide a variety of meals and snacks in our Cafe which caters for all dietery needs. We also provide a full timetable of daily activities. Our service users vary in age from 60 to 95 years of age and are mostly what is considered of low to moderate needs. We have several service users with varying mental health problems including learning difficulties.

West Ealing's Age Concern Day Centre is located in two sheltered housing units both close to local amenities and run in partnership with Catalyst Housing Association. Most of our service users come for lunch which is provided by a local cafe and offers a two-course meal of very high quality ensuring they receive their daily nutrition and feel generally well fed and satisfied. Some of our service users spend half a day with us but most arrive around mid-morning and stay well into the afternoon. They can choose whether to come just once a week or more often.West Ealing Day Centre operates Mondays to Fridays 10.30am to 3pm.

A Telephone support service up to five days weekly for Older people who are at risk and who are vulnerable. This could be those who are housebound, isolated or at risk etc. An Overview assessment is carried out by the Coordinator at the service users home and a case plan is drawn up. The telephone callers follow the case plan when undertaking calls. They provide information, advice and assistance with solving problems. Regular reviews are carried out at the service users home up to four times a year by the Coordinator.

A Week day office hours service providing a finger and toenail cutting for older people who live in the London Borough of Ealing. Aimed at assisting those who are unable to undertake this task themselves. Treatment is carried out at an Ealing Borough surgery point or in the persons own home. The Nail technicians employed by ACE are trained by Ealing Podiatrists.

The Advice & Information Services operate at our main enquiry centre in West Ealing and also at the Michael Flanders Day Centre; both services operate from 9.00am until 4.00pm each weekday.Enquiries are made via personal callers, telephone or email. We also offer Advocacy Surgeries each week. The Welfare Benefits Service has a weekly Surgery and also undertakes form-filling and benefit checks at clients homes or in-house 5 days per week. The service has paid staff and a team of volunteers also.

Telecare pendant alarm scheme. The criteria is a history or risk of falls. The pendant alarm scheme enables service users to call for assistance via the response centre in the event of a fall. A home visit assessment is carried out by the coordinator to establish that the person has a land line and a power source to enable installation. A key holder must be identified or a key safe put in place.

Falls Prevention Service. Trained home hazard assessors visit people in their own homes to carry out a safety assessment. Those referred have either had a fall or feel they are at risk of falling. We then arrange for minor repairs and alterations to be done by the council handyperson service. Repairing carpets, removing/changing unsuitable positioning of furniture, improving lighting and installing grab rails inside and outside of the home are some examples of work undertaken to reduce falls. We also discuss other matters relating to falls prevention this includes footwear, eyesight testing, diet to be high in vitamin D and calcium (preventing multiple fractures in Osteoporotic patients) polypharmacey, exercise etc.
Counselling service to clients with mild to moderate mental health difficulties.
A weekly Carer Training Support Programme for family members supporting individuals affected by substance misuse issues.

Breakaway is a free service that gives people with learning difficulties aged 20-65, the chance to have time away from home doing something they enjoy. Breakaway also gives people the chance to make friends, learn new skills and access the community. The service also supports families, enabling them to take respite breaks, from what is ofetn a full time caring responsibility. In total Breakaway offers a choice of six activity sessions, for four hours each. These run fortnightly, delivering three, four hour sessions a week. The activities and group numbers are as follows, Pottery 8, Drama 9, Going Places 6, Music 8, Woodwirk 10, Art 10, totalling 51 people. Breakaway also provides a transport to and from the service.

The Out & About Project is for people with learning disabilities in the Borough of Ealing, who require a minimal level of support. Its purpose is to encourage members to participate in the social events and activities that being "Out and About" in the wider community has to offer, by exposure to new experiences and places, by building confidence and travel skills, and through making new friends. Sessions are run three times a week and always well attended.

SDC operates from 2 sites both of which are open every day. Supported activities are provided Mon-Fri for more frail/disabled persons. Service provision (Mon-Fri) includes day care, exercises, yoga, luncheon meals, health information, social and recreationsl activities, music, bingo, reading, tea service. This is supported by welfare casework and a trasnport service. On weekends a basic drop-in service in for users playing card games, reading room, and general socialising with a tea service is provided.

Carers Support Service - To provide carers of a person with a severe and enduring mental illness, one on one support, advocacy, information, advice, training and access to support groups and respite schemes. Service is provided daily to a number of clients with frequency of meeting determined by clients needs.

Somali Mental Health Support Project provide culturally appropriate advice and information to Somali refugees experiencing Mental Health problems and their relatives on services available and How to access these services to enable them to make informed choice.

Centre based weekday care services (each weekday Monday to Friday). Services inlude dedicated advice and advocacy services, health promotion and preventative health activities and services, socialisation, learning and educational services, counselling and mediation, inter generation projects, activities and services recognising and celebrating cultural identity and heritage alongside the promotion of diversity and bringing all communities together.

Organisation_Name: Ealing Social Club for the Blind
Services_Provided: Our users are registered blind or partially sighted residents of the borough. our sevices meets the following needs of our users: social interaction, opportunity to form new friendships, provision of relevant information, provision of entertainment, provision of transport. The Club meets once a month.

Scheme_Name: Boston Manor & William Hobbayne Pop-in sessions
Services_Provided: We encourage the development of Pop-Ins which help maintain independence and nuture friendship among active older people. The Pop-Ins are places where older people can enjoy refreshments and socialise each week. Birthdays and other festive days are celelbrated. Activities such as crafts, computer use, holidays, and day/evening trips, for example to the theatre, Christmas Markets, lunches and the seaside are regularly organised and greatly enjoyed.

Cape is a day service for individuals with mental health difficulties living in the London Borough of Ealing. We provide vocational and recreational support for our clients. We run groups e.g drumming, hearing voices group, walk for wellbeing, choir, IT sessions and support groups. We run a womens only and outrewach service. We are open 5 days a week including a Sunday

Scheme_Name: Respite service for carers in their own home
Services_Provided: We provide a regular weekly 2 - 3 hr session in the home of the carer to enable them to have a break from caring. The service we provide can vary depending on what the client would like, for example: light house work, making a light snack, keep company, read too, taking the cared for to a social club or local shopping, this will then enable the carer to attend to their own needs and appointments as many have their own health issues and cannot always get out in order to sort these out.

Providing culturally sensitive support to carers and their families. Providing up to four hours care per family per week at times and days that suit the carer. Supporting isolated older people whose carers do not live with them. Preventing admission into hospital/residential care of a person with a disability should there be a breakdown of care in the family household. Liasing with statutory agencies, purchasers and providers on how services can be adapted to meet the needs of the older Asian people and their carers. Providing emergency care and support to carers who are unaware of or are not using existing services. RESPITE CARE: the provision of culturally appropriate packages to meet the individual need and requirements of carers, via care plans decided in conjunction with service users/carers. PERSONAL CARE: bathing, feeding, washing, dressing, assisting with mobilising and transfers. HOME HELP: light housework, cooking and shopping. COMMUNITY CARE ASSESSMENTS: detailed assessments of users' and carers' needs ensuring that cultural, religious and gender issues are considered in care planning and management. REFERALS: enable carers to access services where we cannot help. FREQUENCY OF SERVICE: Once to Twice a week and 2 to 4 hours a week, depending upon the needs of the client and carer.

Organisation_Name: Centre for Armenian Information and Advice
Services_Provided:
Twice Weekly personalised and flexible short breaks for Armenian Carers in 
LB of Ealing either in their homes or at CAIA at Day Centre.
We provide the following for people in receipt of care. Some Carers are
older people who look after their wives/husbands and therefore as our
service is flexible, some will come together, some (be they carers or Cared
for) come alone.
1- Free door to door transport (this is not funded by the Carers Grant) to
attend Day Centre twice a week as well as benefit from activities/services
taking place at the Day Centre. As a result , the above provision benefits 
both for Carers and those cared for in different ways.
For example for the Carer it allows them to have respite from Caring duties
as we provide lunch for those being cared for, opportunity for cared for the
socialise with their peers, take part in mild forms of exercises, benefit
from health promotional and cultural events,etc. Sometimes its the other way round. 
The Carer attends the Day Centre and has a break by socialising with other Carers, 
take part in mild forms of exercises, benefit from health promotional, recreational
and cultural events,etc. Some carers will purchase lunch for the person they
care for as there is no Armenian meals on Wheels. In some cases both the
Carer and Cared for person will come together but enjoy themselves
separately, even if they are married,etc. 
Carers have also attended our Silver Surfer sessions in the past year
enabling them not only to have a break but develop themselves.
2- Home visits/breaks at home
Through home visits we have offered not only breaks for Carers but have
accessed needs of cared for person and where appropriate provided
independent advice and advocacy services to them in their own language.
3- Seaside outing for both, these being cared for and for Carers. Some
Carers chose not to come to have a break, so we took those being looked
after. For some Carers it was the other way round. They chose to come and
made arrangements for someone else to look after the person they normally
look after.

Anchor offers a free, confidential and professional counselling service to all clients of Ealing, suffering from mental health problems to prevent relapse to an episode of serious and enduring mental illness. We are aware of the multicultural nature of this borough, and offer the service with the option of languages, mainly in Polish, Italian, French, Portuguese, Hindi, Urdu, Arabic, Gujrati, Bengali and English. The clients are offered a maximum of 12 sessions and seen weekly. Referrals are received from GPs, Social services, courts, police as well as self referrals.

Our services focus around our lunch clubs which is supported by provision of transport. We are open 5 days a week and operate 2 lunch clubs.In addition to this we have day trips and holiday during the year. We are able to offer a hearing aid service as well as health advice through a health trainer within the club and also as an outreach service in the community.Our IT support service is very popular and has been accessed by over 25 people.In addition we have a gardening service assessed by our members when requested.A volunteer service is available for our more active members.On a weekly basis we also offer a hairdressing service and knitting club.Toenail service is available on an appoitment service.

AFCS provides individual counselling to those in the Asian community with mental health issues. It also runs at least two theme-based groups for 6 sessions at a time through the year. (It does provide a family service but data for these users are not included in the return)

Luncheon & social club providing a) weekely luncheon meeting; b) exercises for healthy hearts; c) interactive fun programmes e.g. quizes, storytelling; d) dancing & friendships; e) dissemination od statutory information, referral to agancies, & help with communication; f)workshops on disease, healthy cooking/eating, healthy lifestyles. Outreach service: home help (domestic chores, shopping, chaperoning to dentists, hospitals, etc., help with reading & writing letters - all with vetted volunteers,

Support, conversation, discussions, games, activities and personal care are provided in the home for people with dementia while their carers can take a break from their caring duties. Much more detailed information can be found on the scheme's webpage at http://www.dementiaconcern.co.uk/services/callcare.html.
Day Care
Monitoring for people living alone in the community
Assessment, advice & information, support & independent advocacy

All clients have mental health issues impinging on personal and family life. They are given individual assessments and placed into either one-to-one counselling or into groups relating to men and women's anger management & men's personal development. Supervision of all counselling practitioners
Monthly meeting for people with epilepsy & their carers/families.

Mencap Carer Services work with the Ethnic Minorities Access and Participation Project to provide service users with culturally appropriate activites at weekends away from home and to give respite to their carers for this time.

Provide respite for carers by providing activity sessions on a regular basis for people with learning difficulties. These can include bowling, sports activities, shopping, eating out, cinema, parks and horse-riding.
Supports people with learning disabilities to provide consultancy and passes relevant information about what is happening in Ealing
The project helps people with learning disabilities advocate on behalf or other people with disabilities. Part of the project also checks up on supported living schemes and respite services
Help & advice regarding social services, education & nhs provision for people with LD and their carers

The project helps people with learning disabilities plan their lives and help them get the support they need. The project uses a lot of multi-media to support the service user in making choices and empowering them to think of their future

Helps people with learning disabilities with information and advice about housing, specifically supporting service users with shared ownership and making bids for housing and understanding the different housing options

The project looks at further developing people with learning disabilities in Ealing. Supporting them to understand local policy and authority workings, partnership boards, consultation. It also works in areas such a hate crime and training.

We provide IAG to our Deaf and Hard of Heariang clients during our drop in surgery.The times for drop in surgery are Tuesdays and Thursdays 10am-1pm and Wednesdays 1.30-4.30pm, other times by appointments only, We open Mondays to Fridays 9.30am - 5pm. We do the form fillings, translation from written or spoken English to British Sign Langauge. We attend tribunal hearings with our clients relating to their benefits. We give support to clients with housing issues. We undertake full assessements on new clients either at the office or at ther home if they are housebound to ensure their entitlements are up to date and accurate. We do the telephone calls on their behalf or their requests.

Carry out carers assessment to gather information for clientswith hearing loss in Ealing Borough who cares for another person on home visits. Enter details on our carers database. Provide information on carers network and support organisation as needed. Signpost to other organsation (with permission) as needed.

Make referrals to Services for Visually Impaired Team (SVIP) for registration for new clients who have been diagnosed as deaf blind. Arrange home visits to carry out assessment for new clients who have been referred to us. Advise clients which specialist equipment to aid with sight may be suitable and liaise with SVIP. Make referrals to te Equipment Officer at deafPLUS for equipment provision. Check what welfare benefits clients receive and which they may be eligible to receive. Make referals to Social Services if clients need other help. Continued support / follow up for existing deafblind clients.

We provide equipment to match thir needs for Deaf and Hard of Hearing clients also we assess their needs for new clients to ensure they get the right equipment to support their needs. We make home visits in the afternoons on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays.
This Service provides communication support for Deaf and Hard of Hearing people through B.S.L Interpreters or Lip Speakers for G.P/ Hospital appointments

Run for senior citizens, the aim is to make them feel secure, happy, warm & comfortable, they are provided with a place to meet daily in an atmosphere of care & compassion. They can discuss problems relating to health or daily occurances. Also offer advice on dealing with services; help with writing letters, accompanying to appointments; translation services.

Information, advice and advocacy for the disabled community and carers in London Borough of Ealing, including Outreach surgeries, Law for All surgeries and quarterly Independent Living surgeries, as well as one off information and social events.

Resource and support centre for all unpaid carers, of any age, in the borough. The centre is open Monday-Friday and provides, all year round, drop-in advice and resource informationto both carers and cared-for people. They also provide holistic therapies; exercise classes; an internet cafe; occasional workshops on topics of interest to carers eg careers advice and manual handling & lifting. The centre hosts carers networking groups and works in partnership with statutory and non-statutory agencies to enhance services for carers.

We provide a Housing Support Service which consists of two projects, one in Somerset Road in Chiswick and the other in Eccleston Road in West Ealing. These consist of self-contained flats and work within an agreed support plan which aids the tenants in maintaining the tenancies in semi-independent and shared homes

These supply a variety of social activities and emotional support with relationship building, social inclusion and relapse prevention as the main aims. We also provide advocacy services for in-patients at the West Middlesex and Ealing Hospitals and community advocacy services serving the Boroughs of Ealing and Hounslow.

These supply a variety of social activities and emotional support with relationship building, social inclusion and relapse prevention as the main aims. Individualised support to people with severe and enduring mental health problems into mainstream employment, education or volunteering. Telephone and a drop in service. Provides information and advice on benefits, housing, social care, transport, leisure and social activities and most other things that affect the quality of life for older residents in Harrow. This service is for all older residents of Harrow and their carers.

The advocacy project aims to offer independent support to older people 60+ living in the London Borough of Harrow. The advocacy project aims to help people say what they want, secure their rights, represent their interests, and obtain services they require. Age Concern Harrow exist to promote the well being of all older people in the London Borough of Harrow and to make life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience. The service provides information to help the older person make informed choices about their care. The service allows the older person contact with the outside world and tries to eliminate exclussion and lonliness. The service also aims to provide practicle solutions to problems that may arise.

Day care service providing activities for those suffering from Alzheimers. Citizen Advocacy - Advocacy Partners recruits, trains and supports volunteer Citizen Advocates. A Citizen Advocate's role is to represent the interests of another person with the same commitment as if they were their own interests and to provide a link into community life for people who otherwise may be isolated. Advocacy Partners supports Citizen Advocates for people with disabilities, particularly those with learning disabilities.

Professional Advocacy - We employ staff to provide a focused individual advocacy service. This service provides support and representation, including to people with very complex needs and those who require major changes in their lives. We also supervise a team of trained volunteers who support people in this way.

Independent Mental Capacity Advocacy (IMCA) - In order to promote and safeguard the interests of people who may otherwise be amongst the most vulnerable, we provide a statutory IMCA service. This ensures that independent support and representation is provided by trained advocates to people who are assessed to lack capacity to make particular decisions about serious medical treatment or where they live.

Self Advocacy and Involvement - Advocacy Partners provides independent support to people with learning disabilities. We support people with learning disabilities to run Self Advocacy groups. These enable people to provide mutual support, raise common issues and to ensure that these are addressed. We also support people with learning disabilities to work collectively to input into the planning and development of services.
