Our Leaving Hospital Support Service team provide daily visits to all wards at Royal Bournemouth Hospital daily including A&E cover. We receive & action referrals from all professionals who have identified patient & carers who have complex or low care Social need issues on the wards. Where complex social issues have been identified we would visit the patient and gaining consent would refer the service user to Social Services by completing a Single Assessment Process form. If it has been identified on our visit to the patient that there are low care needs such as domestic, shopping, meal provider agencies etc, we can provide factsheet information on these services. Our service also provides Advocacy support and signposting wherever needed, enabling service user to access other agencies such as Housing, Benefits & Social clubs. The team ensure a person centred approach is given to the patient & carers at all times, by listening and being as informative as possible to ensure a safe discharge from hospital.
A Befriending Service for Carers: The FOCUS Scheme provides volunteers who will befriend those whom are Carers. Volunteers will telephone, visit or meet up with the Carer outside of the home.

Wellbeing service for the over 65s, which seeks to help older people access appropriate local services in order to maintain/improve their independence; frequency depends on the needs of the client but is usually weekly.

EDAS objectives through their treatment programme are that service users will be able to recognise that maintaining change is difficult. There maybe increased vulnerability as people are trying to cope without substances (or with reduced supply) and, for some people, being drug free means that their mental health problems may escalate. EDAS treatment programmes aim to heighten service users' awareness around the positive factors of what they need to live life on life terms.  Social support networks;  Stable living situation;  Safe, structured environment;  Sense of purpose - job/hobbies;  Therapeutic discussion;  Practical help;  Insight & awareness;  Physical well-being;  Medication (maximum effectiveness, minimal inconvenience and side-effects. In addition EDAS provides Drug Rehabilitation Requirements (DRR) and Alcohol Treatment Requirement (ATR), which is an Order of the Court and follows a Sentence of a Community Order or a Suspended Sentence. The drug rehabilitation programme, which lasts between 2 and 3 years, might involve counselling, substitute prescribing* or attending a day-centre. The provision of Alcohol Treatment Service can also be through counselling. * The drug rehabilitation programme is not necessarily or specifically health lead and the delivery of specific counselling and day-centre provision would make EDAS eligible under the GFS 2010/11 guidance (page 10).

This service supports carers of adults with severe and enduring mental health problems, offering emotional and practical support on a one to one and group basis. Carers need to be supporting someone aged 18-65 who is on CPA or who would be eligible for CPA but does not access secondary support. The service administrates respite funds for carers of severe and enduring mental health problems. To receive respite the recipient must be a part of the CPA process.

Poole CAB provides an information & advice service 15 hours per week at St Ann's hospital targeting adults with mental health problems. Provides welfare benefits advice to all patients. Provides Advocacy in 2 parts: 1) general advocacy services to all clients of the Community Mental Health Team 2) provides Independent Mental Health Advocacy services specifically for people who have been detained on Sections of the Mental Health Act.

Advocacy Service for individuals with Mental Health problems, who live within the Bournemouth & Poole postcode and are under the care of a Community Mental Health Team. The service operates Monday - Friday, 9am - 5pm.

Steven James Counsellling offers weekly 1 to 1 counselling with fully qualified counsellors in the Poole, Dorset area. In addition to being fully qualified our counsellors are either already accredited or working towards accreditation. We work with clients experiencing a range of issues including addiction, blood borne viruses, gambling problems, bereavenment, anxiety, depression and stress.

Brendoncare runs 6 clubs for older people in the Poole Council Area under a 12 month contract that has recently been extended. Four Open Days for older people's services were run during the 12 months involving over 1,000 people and we run a Well Being Centre in Poole that has received 640 visitors.

Comprehensive and specialist rehabilitation and support for brain injured adults and their families throughout Dorset. Services run by appointment during week days include physiotherapy, psychology, occupational therapy, ad-hoc memory groups (ave. 2 x 8 sessions per year) 1 x weekly drop in Poole and Dorchester. Carer support meetings 1 x month and home visits during weekdays. Extensive home visits by Community multidisiplinary team.

Support people with a learning disability who live in and around Poole with self advocacy. Run weekly drop in sessions. Run social groups on a monthly basis (Mens, womens, Outdoor fitness and film club). Advise organisations including the BoP on making information accessible. Provide a service to BoP and other organisations making leaflets and information easy to read. Support service users to attend the Poole Learning Disability Partnership Board and the associated action groups. Hold regular (4 times a year) Big meetings for members. Issue a quarterly newsletter in easy read. Promote the rights of individuals with a learning disability. Provide training to organisations on disability awareness.

Short term breaks for carers, a varying number of breaks are arranged on a daily basis. Carers link: telephone helpline for carers offering information and support, including 40 different factsheets. Signposting. Drop in sessions in 2 Poole locations, each held 1 x weekly. Promotion at events of carers services. Frequency - varying volumes of calls on a daily basis, a busy service.

We run a Supported Volunteering Project, which recruits and trains volunteer buddies to provide one to one support to th ose previously unable to volunteer with us, due to high support needs. The Supported Volunteering Project specifically enables those who are in particular need of support, whether due to disability or for any other reason, to take a full and active part in society, learn new skills, make a contribution to their local community, and to work and socialise with people from all backgtrouns and walks of life.

Rethink a support group for Mental Health Carers and individuals suffering from Mental Health issues in Fareham and Gosport. Providing Practical and positive support, ensureing empowerment through effective services, information and support. We provide a voice and unique insight with the objective to recover a better quality of life as part of Rethink National. From January 2011 we provide a fun evening including an 'Oasis of Calm' (which is a pampering session of beauty therapies, massage, relaxation techniques for carers and those suffering from mental health issues on the first Thursday of every month, and on the 2nd and 4th Thurs a confidential session especially for carers. Additionally during the year we organise extra events, such as bbq's, music events, arts and crafts etc, as of Feb we will have a weekly afternoon drop in session for drinks, food and socialising, mainly for users and carers.
Social Support + Training, Health & Fitness, Activities, Therapies

Scheme_Name: East Hants Service User Involvement Project
Services_Provided: We support service users to become involved in all aspects of service position. We run a resource center that is manned by service users and they provide IT lessons for other service users. They sit on interview panels, attend meetings and conferences, write information booklets and newsletters, provide training, do teaching sessions in universities and colleges, they do weekly drop in sessions in in-patient units and help other service users to complete WRAPs. They takek part in monitoring services and do audits. We are a seven day week service that works flexibly with members over weekends and evenings as well. Members are free to do as much or as little as they want.

Services_Provided: Community Development Worker - Community Innovations Team for Hart and Rushmoor. The Community Innovations Team is a multi-disciplinary team made up of staff from hampshire County Council's Adult Services and the local Councils for Voluntary Service. The overall aim of the team is to work with individual older people over the age of 65 who are not yet at the point of needing a full package of care, but who are beginning to find certain areas of their lives more difficult, and are perhaps struggling to continue to live independently in their own homes. The role of the Communhity Development Wrokder within this team is to provide information on community-based services that could be accessed by older people, to help with the recruitment of volunteers if required, to help local groups develop and maintain their services by providing advice on funding and governance, and to develop new services where gaps are identified.

We strive to raise awareness of the effects of head injury on the person and the family, and help people re-integrate in the community.

We deliver two different types of programme for older adults. Firstly, our Programme of Activities for Older Adults (PAOA), which offers affordable exercise classes for the over 50's, and secondly, our Social Wellbeing (SWB) programme, which delivers exercise sessions free of charge in sheltered accommodation schemes and day centres. Our programmes support Hampshire County Council's priority of 'Maximising Wellbeing' as they aim to improve local residents' quality of life and help to ensure that they can live independently for as long as possible by providing them with opportunities and support to improve and maintain their physical health. They also promote social well-being by bringing people together; helping to ensure that participants enjoy positive mental health, and counteracting social exclusion. They focus on disadvantaged local residents, ensuring that opportunities and access to services are made available to those who need them most.

This service has expanded in the last year and we have based our figures on the following information: 
The service reported that it had:
16 new referrals in the survey week
31 Installs
On top of this the service had 4117 calls for support; the service used their call management system to break down the call data for us to ensure that we were not counting people twice. This amounted to 869 individual people. Then next step was that we needed to deduct those people that would have a package of care. Based on information from a recent CSED report which estimated that 28% of the people that the service supports had a package of care. We then deducted 28% from the 869 people which gave us a total of 679. 
This in total gave us the 726 reported.
The calls the service deals with can be varied and this requires a range of involvement from the team. For example, this could include clients who have had fall, so staff might visit the client to make sure they are safe or they might need to then arrange help for them or organise an ambulance. The service gets involved in ensuring that the person has support in their home a number of the services clients have dementia.

Provision of Employment and Training Support. Richmond Fellowship Employment and Training are a member of the Swindon Occupational Partnership, providing services to people with Mental Health problems. They provide in depth one-to-one advice and guidance sessions carried out by qualified Careers Advisers. All client work is client-centred and with the ultimate goal of employment. In addition clients will be able to access Vocational Assessment, Benefit Information, advice on opportunities for part-time and full-time employment and access to a variety of Jobcentre Plus services. Clients will be supported to engage in on site training i.e. Introduction to Computers, CLAIT (Computer Literacy & Information Technology), Beating the Blues CBT, Interview Skills; CV Skills; and Job Club.

Day Centre for service users over 60 years of age. Transport provided via disabled access minibuses. Two-course freshly cooked lunch provided daily. Open Monday-Friday 9am-4.30pm. Service users attend 1-3 days per week. Activities include bingo, quizes, games, nintendo Wii, ds lite. Afternoon and daytime trips and visiting entertainers. Craft room and computer room available daily. Other services provided bathing, footcare, hairdressers, community footcare, home from hospital scheme, chair based dance classes. Insurance arranger on site.

Day services - Day centre operating Mon-Fri. Transport provided via disabled access minibuses. Freshly cooked lunch provided daily. Activities including bingo, quizzes, internet, nintendo wii and ds lites. Day and afternoon trips, visiting entertainers, chair based dance classes. Clinics including chiropody and falls prevention.
Visiting service users over the age 60 years old in their own homes to bath/shower.This service is one visit per person per week.
Community Social Centre Drop-In and whole day. Monday to Friday, Transport, Meals and Activities
Weekly bathing service
A weekly day care centre. We provide hot meals, exercise classes, English class, Chinese newspaper and magazines etc.

Welcome Day Centre is a day care centre for elderly people from ethnic minorities. We provide help, support and guidance on various issues. We run our own transport to pick and drop our clients. We support healthy living and independent lifestyle. We have yoga classes every week. We organise day trips to various places every three months or on clients' request. We serve freshly cooked vegetarian food.
Day Care for OPMH (Mon-Fri).

Equinox is an organization that provides community based service to service users with alcohol, drug and mental health issues. The service provides a number of services; 1:1 counselling and support for 8 sessions. Our floating support service is for service users with alcohol,mental health and housing issues within their homes. Tis can last up to 18 months and can help and support service users reintergrate back into the communty through voluntary work, employment and education. The service is able to support the service users through reintergration by joint working with other angecies.
IT training to adults with mental illness. Students attend once or twice a week for 2.5 hours.
One2One issue based advocacy to people who are funded by Medway
Advocacy for citizens of Medway affected by mental distress
Self advocacy group for adults with a learning disability
We provide BSL interpreters, lipspeakers, notetakers and STTR's for Deaf people across Kent, Essex, London and the South East

Services for D/deaf adults with learning disabilities and mental health challenges. RAD supports D/deaf adults with additional needs to live independently as possible. We provide the following: Community Support Service, Groups, Communication Support, Advocacy Support, Hearing Assessments and Makaton and alternative communication training

KASBAH provide a range of support services to individuals and families who care for a person with Spina Bifida and/or Hydrocephalus. This support includes 1-2-1 support, advocacy, advice and information. KASBAH also specialises in training young adults in daily living skills such as cooking, budgeting and keeping safe, this service is open to any person with the potential to learn and to develop.

We provide a mobility and rehabilitation service for all ages, to anyone whose vision cannot be corrected with spectacles. We issue equipment on behalf of Medway Council under the FACS criteria, and complete the registration service for people being registered either SI/partially sighted or SSI/blind.

Transport (provided daily). A community transport scheme to take elderly or disabled clients to hospital and medical appointments/social groups/etc.    Befriending (provided daily) Befrienders visit elderly, house-bound people to improve the quality of their lives. Mentors help people who are isolated to work through their difficulties and regain their place in society. Gardening (provided weekly) Gardeners perform routine garden maintenance for elderly or disabled people who are no longer able to look after them themselves. Enables people to stay in their homes for longer. Volunteering (provided daily) Provide a brokerage service to find, place and support volunteers and organisations.  ESOL (provided weekly) Free English language lessons to help people integrate into local community and improve work prospects.

Transport for elderly and less able people to hospitals and other medical/social/day centre appointments - daily (including weekends). Befriending elderly and less able people in their own homes (weekends, evenings, day time). Lunch Club - elderly people - fortnightly. Volunteeing support for less able (including learning difficulties) - ongoing. Volunteer Brokerage - non profit making and charitable organisations - ongoing.

Scheme_Name: Elected Representatives Medway Learning Disability Partnership Board
Services_Provided: To support the current elected representatives (for people with a learning disability to take part in the 2010/11 Learning Disability Partnership Board elections. To support current representatives, if any, that are not re-elected to have a positive experience leaving their partnership board role. To support self-advocates to communictae their wishes, choices and aspirations, in all areas of life. To support the newly elected 2010/2011 representatives of people with a learning disability, on the Learning Disability Partnership Board, to direct the support they need to make a positive contribution to the board. Directly supporting the access to and civic particpation of people with a learning disability through regular weekly contact with elected representatives and constituency members, and representation of issues impacting on the lived experience at LDPB meetings.
Provides signposting and information, tailored to the individuals need, for people with dementia and their carers.

Hi Kent provides an Assessment service on behalf of Medway Council for d/Deaf persons over 65 years old, whose first language is not BSL. Hi Kent also provides a range of services through its role as a charity. These include a drop in centre for visitors to the Medway Hospital, (where clients can try out assistive equipment), lipreading tuition, BSL tuition, Hearing Aid aftercare services, including free battery and tubing supply. Hi Kent also provides an advice and information service for all d/Deaf persons, their carers and any other persons supporting their welfare.

A signposting/navigation service to people who under FACS are assessed as having a low or moderate care need. We also provide assistance in completeing benefit application forms. The service is available mon - fri.

Living Well works in conjunction with Medway Council and Medway Citizens Advice Bureau. Living Well provides a free information and advice service to individuals who have low to moderate care needs to remain independent in their own home. People can refer themselves, or be referred by others including health and social care providers as well as family members. The service covers Chatham, Rochester, Strood and the Villages. Living Well is managed and supervised from the Medway Citizens Advice Bureau, Chatham. Interviews, telephone helpline and drop-ins are available from 09.30 to 16.30 Monday to Friday. If possible, home visits may be undertaken if necessary; however these will be dependent on available resources at the time of request.
Information, advice and support to family carers aged 5 - 93 years of age both individually and in groups

24 hour telephone counselling, information and advice helpline service provided, via freephone, to Carers throughout Medway. Option for Carer to self-refer for face to face counselling (up to six sessions per referral)

We provide one-to-one and telephone support to carers of people with dementia, also have a monthly carers group, monthly coffee morning, monthly "singalong", weekly Tai Chi, twice monthly pamper sessions, regular outings and events. Our service provides emotional and practical support in recognition of the needs of families affected by dementia. The aim of the service is to reduce the impact of crisis situations on health and social care.
Advice and information for Mental Health clients. Training of independent brokers.
Hot Meal Delivery. Aim is to keep people in their own homes by supplying hot meals 365 days a year, company and a health and saftey check.
Supplying meals
Weekly visits to vulnerable people in their place of residence. Pratical help, including tenancy support

Providing person centred advocacy services based on induviduals circumstances. Helping vulnerable people to communicate more effectively with organisations such as banks, local authorities and utility companies.

Therapist rehabilitation for people with long term conditions to enable them greater independence at home or on return from hospital

Peer-led support services for people with strokes, including weekly conversation groups (7), a county-wide befriending service, hubs (3) of active citizens and training and awareness raising, year round
Individual issue based advocacy for vulnerable individuals in the community with a learning disability. On occasion crisis advocacy. Service is offered Monday - Friday

We offer counselling to newly diagnosed VI persons or their close relatives. We also provide befriending visits.
We provide transport so that visually impaired people can meet and have some social or sporting interaction. We have choir, shooting, bowling, gardening, riding.

Award small grants to organisations in Cornwall. The fund aims to prevent and help people aged 16 plus who need extra support to live as independently as possible. The focus of projects must be on social inclusion and integration

Day care and home visiting for elderly visually impaired. Social, craft, activities weekly clubs (Mon - Thur) and fortnightly dance club. Providing one stop practical and emotional support

The service offers one to one support to carers through visits, phone calls, email, etc and provides information, advice and emotional support

There are 3 community support workers (1 in each locality team). They provide practical help, support and advice to vulnerable clients with substance misuse problems, often at their homes pre and post detox and rehab as part of their reintegration into society

Person centred support to ensure people with drug and alcohol problems make effective use of REHAB, and return home without set backs. Workers provide pre and post detox personalised support and advice.

DIAl has one full time line manager and two part time independent living advisers who provide free, independent and confidential telephone advice and support to people with disabilities, their families and carers and to voluntary and statutory organisations on any disability related enquiry. The advice line is open Monday to Friday between 10 and 3 with an answer machine facility outside of office hours

Enable in Cornwall is a registered charity that works with people aged 16 to 64 who have a physical disability and/or sensory impairment and live in Cornwall. The organization offers free information, advice, guidance and support to assist clients in overcoming barriers they may face in accessing training, education, voluntary work or paid employment. Moreover, the organization devotes the time and resources necessary to empower disabled citizens to assume active and purposeful roles in their communities.
Providing volunteering opportunities for adults with learning disabilities

Voluntary community transport for all classes pf persons for whom public or private transport is not an option including vulnerable people and the elderly. The service is available 24 hours a day, every day of the year.

Dementia Carers' is a free service commissioned from Outlook South West by the Cornwall and Isles of Scilly Primary Care Trust and Cornwall Council. This service offers information, advice and help to carers who are living at home looking after a person with dementia. Support is delivered to carers by: (a) offering free information sessions across the county, approximately two/three sessions a week, (b) carers who attend the Cognitive Stimulation Therapy sessions offered by the CFT - 5 week blocks as and when across the county, (c) support is offered to carers who are not able to leave their homes for reasons of their own - home visits are set up as and when. A free Dementia Carer booklet (designed by Outlook SW.) is given to all who participate in the information sessions, CST carer groups and home visits.

We are funded through the Learning Disability Partnership Board and Cornwall Adult Care and Support - Learning Disabilities. We provide training, advice and support to people with learning disabilities, their families and their supporters around person centred approaches and planning. We also provide a service called Get A Plan in Cornwall which is an advice, information and support network (email: getaplanincornwall@hotmail.co.uk) for people with learning disabilities, their families and supporters to plan for their future.
Care and Repair assists older people over 60 and disabled people of all ages to find the best answer to their housing needs and to live in greater comfort and security in their own homes

Services_Provided: Drop-in service for those aged 55+ providing games, three course lunch and transport, Monday to Friday.

Active Living Centre, drop-in service for the elderly who are in need of day care due to isolation, lack of mobility, medical problems (mental and physical) or disabled. Active Living Centre, drop-in service for those aged 50+ providing activities such as bingo, line dancing, sing-song and exercise, crafts, information, lunches and health talks.

Activities are provided on a regular basis to all adults aged 50+ to prevent isolation or depression within the rural areas.

Active Living Centre, drop-in service for those aged 50+ providing activities, flexercise, sing-a-long entertainment, arts and crafts. Activities generally take place monthly at sheltered housing schemes.

Active Living/Mini-Day Centre, drop-in service for those aged 50+ providing lunch, lunch outings, harvest table, exercise, activities such as scrabble, cards, dominoes and bowls, as well as tea and coffee.

A community centre, drop-in service open Monday to Friday, providing cardiovascular risk assessment health checks for those aged 40 to 74 living in Somerset, a Tai Chi based gentle exercise class for those aged 50+, information, advice surgeries and weekly/monthly clubs such as a social group, computer group, lunch club and craft classes to support residents of North Taunton. The centre is accessible to wheelchairs.
Active Living/Day Centre, drop-in service for those aged 50+ providing lunch, activities both active and craft based, and information on social inclusion and well being.

Organisation_Name: Asian Health and Social Care Association
Services_Provided:
Day Centre for South Asian Elderly people of Bristol and South Gloucestershire-wide. Our aim is
to assist our members to try and live an independent life as possible by providing a healthy vegetarian
lunch, day trips, light exercise, shopping trips, aromatherapy, head massage, reiki, footcare and indoor
activities i.e. darts, cards and board games. We are a lifeline for our members who may have become
isolated from their families due to not having the capacity to become carers or unable to enjoy a
independent life within their homes. Our priorities are to keep our elderly membership active and independent.
The association will consider and promote the health and social care needs of the elderly within the South
Asian communities living in the area of benefit, as defined by the funding authorities. The association will
promote the relief of the elderly, who may be vulnerable, have special needs or face Hardship, i.e. those
who are physically and mentally disabled, those suffering from the effects of old age and those who face
poverty.

Scheme_Name: North Somerset CAB Mental Health Income Maximisation
Services_Provided: A specific service for Mental health clients separate from the general service provision. Specific services incude: To provide a quality welfare rights, advice and information service that meets the specific needs of Service Users with mental health issues. To maximise the take up of welfare benefits for MH Service Users. To assist MH Service Users to claim and obtain their full entitlement to benefits and enable them to contribute towards the cost of community care services arranged for them. To minimise the impact of mental illness on a person's life by offering advice and information that empowers the MH Service User to regain control of their circumstances. To prioritise the provision of welfare rights advice and information to those meeting the criteria. To make referrals to other CAB services or signpost to other services where appropriate.

Scheme_Name: Handy Person and Home Safety Assessment Voucher Scheme
Services_Provided:
The Service Provider shall manage the voucher scheme which involves the following activities:
Receive referrals for the Service, following agreed processes and using pro-formas designed for the service.
Provide advice and information about the scheme to individuals and statutory or third sector organisations. 
Record Service Users details on a database.
Distribute vouchers to Health Care Assistants who will undertake a health and wellbeing check and distribute the vouchers to Service Users, or distribute vouchers direct to Service User where this has been identified as the preferred route.
Obtain Service User consent to share where this has not been undertaken already.
Pass client information to the HIA Provider. 
Receive and monitor invoices from the HIA Provider along with the Assessment and action plan, signed job sheet and matched voucher; checking them against the schedule of tasks (see Appendix Three for detail regarding expectations, costs and tasks in respect of the HIA Service provision to assist with financial reconciliation). Please note that confidentiality must be maintained regarding HIA Provider information as with all information relating to this agreement.
Manage the demand of the Service according to volumes available and budget, the Service Purchaser to forecast under/over spend based on information submitted by the Service Provider. 
Follow up any inaccuracies on invoices with the HIA Provider.
Forward invoices, Assessment and action plan, signed job sheet and matched voucher number from the HIA provider to the Service Purchaser for payment when reconciled.

Services_Provided: Community Support - The Sidmouth Help Link is a voluntary support group offering one to one support and also group activities to elderly, infirm and vulnerable people in the Sidmouth area. Scheme_Name: Community Support - Support - Northern and Eastern Devon  - Rapid Equipment and Minor Adaptations Service (REMAS)
Services_Provided:
Community Support - The core activity of the Service Provider is to: verify initial assessments undertaken by the Service Purchaser, determine any additional needs through discussions with the Service User and Carer, supply and fit any equipment that is required or; verify initial assessments undertaken by the Service Purchaser, determine any additional needs through discussions with the Service User and Carer, supply fit and/or fix any equipment and/or minor adaptations that are required. The objectives of the Service are to:
Extend the scope of service assessments undertaken which may require the provision of equipment and minor adaptations.
Continue to reduce waiting list for straightforward equipment and minor adaptations across Northern and Eastern Devon.
Provide Service Users with good information and speedy access to assessment and provision of commonly used equipment and minor adaptations.
Select and organise the supply of appropriate equipment and/or minor adaptations as determined by the Service Purchaser.
Provide data information in an electronic format.
Ensure REMAS employees attend relevant training programmes and are competent to provide the Service and any new activity required of them in order to support any further related service activity.
Signpost to Direct Payments for equipment and minor adaptations where this is the choice of the Service User.
Support any further related service activity required by the Service Purchaser by mutual agreement.
Minimise the number of visits required to deliver a straightforward service.

Scheme_Name: Community Support - Teignbridge - Community Support Service
Services_Provided: Community Support - The provision of a range of social care services in the community, which are not provided by statutory agencies, yet are very important in enabling disabled and otherwise vulnerable people to maintain independent living in the community. These services include: Advocacy; Wheelchair escorts; Essential transport; Befriending (to reduce isolation, which can lead to depression, self-neglect and residential care); Bereavement counselling; Assistance in completing benefit forms; Pension collection and limited shopping.

Services_Provided: Community Support - The Service is a GP practise based support scheme in a very rural part of the Mid Devon and East Devon area, covering a large part of the Blackdown Hills. The Service Provider provides a range of services for vulnerable people. The type of community services the Service Provider shall provide include: Volunteer transport to hospital and surgery appointments; Transport into Centres for day care and lunches; Befriending (to reduce isolation, which can lead to depression, self-neglect and residential care); Group and individual support, in an appropriate and timely manner; Practical support including form filling, prescription collection, identifying domestic issues; Support and stimulation to older people, including the elderly frail and vulnerable; Respite for carers, which supports and enhances their ability to continue to provide care for their dependants.

The Senior Council for Devon will: Maintain positive dialogue with Devon County Council and the Primary Care Trust on matters of concern to people aged 50 years and over in the County of Devon. Promote the equality and independence of older people and to promote the equality and independence of the hard to hear or hard to reach for example black and minority ethnic groups, frail older people, carers, people with health and disability related issues. Work to address the issues and priorities of importance to Older People to include those priorities identified in the LinkAge Plus programme. Seek links and positive relationships with representative bodies of other citizen groups e.g. young people, people with learning disabilities and people with mental health problems. Maintain an outward facing approach, encourage membership but ensuring that views of older people over 50 are represented whether they are members or not. Encourage and promote the growth of local groups, targeting areas of high deprivation, and the less populated areas furthest from the urban centres and to provide additional support where this is required to achieve the viability and sustainability of local groups. Facilitate the networking of local groups to relate to sub-county planning groups e.g. Local Strategic Partnerships.

Our volunteers involve themselves in every aspect of BDC's life, in all our groups, transport, fundraising and generally supporting all our activities. The volunteer role with staff support can assist people with low self esteem, confidence and mental health difficulties to return to work. Many of our volunteers have previously accessed our services as users.

The minibus is used for trips and outings as well as our regular journey activities in the Town Hall. These trips offer vulnerable clients the opportunity to socialise. These trips are either half or full days to places of interest and take place monthly with an average of 10 people with staff support.

The lunch club with transport is offered to the most vulnerable clients. This gives the individual many benefits including meeting people, making friends, enjoying a weekly outing and an affordable hot nutritious two course meal. Staff use the opportunity to assess individuals mobility and care needs, etc...

The centre offers a range of services, an open door facility and a cafe with low cost refreshments. Through befriending support each day we offer a minimum of two structured groups/activities. The centre staff also provide person centred, individualised support/information which may include signposting to other service provision. This service directly provides a positive support for people in Brixham to enable them to maximise their independence.

To provide a dedicated carers support worker for 13 hours per week. To offer one to one support to carers and to identify and follow through opportunities to promote the needs through local organisations and other groups. To consider developments to the service, link with other carer support workers and help co-ordinate carer support activity. To support carers groups, produce quarterly newsletter and arrange / organise an annual Brixham Does Care pampering day.

To provide a home visiting befreinding service for older people and adults with physical or mental health problems. This service will attempt to combat loneliness, isolation and despair. It offers one-to one support & monitoring to minimise the likelihood of hypothermia, falls, etc.

This is an advocacy service, providing an Appropriate Adult service to vulnerable adults aged 18+ at the custody suite of Torquay Police Station. The role of the Appropriate Adult is to support and advise a vulnerable adult in police custody and to facilitate communication between them and the police. This person is different to a solicitor and does not give legal advice. This service ensures that vulnerable adults are appropriately supported through advocacy and supports their independence should they have involvement with the Justice system.
